dialogues.speaker: MODY
dialogues.text: Say that again?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: What? Wo man, I was just kidding around. (then; sharply) I just don’t see why the towel boy gets asked for his picture and autograph.

dialogues.speaker: MODY
dialogues.text: You fucking-- Mody stops himself an inch from Ludlow, nostrils flaring. Ludlow is totally unfazed as Wander sternly motions him o

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: Lud!

dialogues.speaker: MODY
dialogues.text: They shouldn’t let you out in the day, you know that?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: That’s fine, Mody. You stay outta my night, I won’t bother you when you’re liaising in Malibu with your shiny fucking boots. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LUDLOW (cont'd) (leaning away) ‘Suspects’ by the way.

dialogues.speaker: MODY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: You called them ‘victims’ the other night. They had two little girls ina cage and they’re called ‘suspects’.

dialogues.speaker: MODY
dialogues.text: Oh, I’m sure that’s what you call them in your chummy little booth. Ludlow passes several booths - notably SHONEY and DEMILLE among a TIGHT FRATERNITY OF DETECTIVES. He flags a far of waiter - making the ‘drink’ motion - before dragging a ch over to Wander, the jovial king among his court. Across the room is CLADY, the piggish Sergeant running la night’s crime scene. Clady stands toasting - and roasting a RETIRING OFFICER (SILKY).

dialogues.speaker: CLADY
dialogues.text: (to all) -.-and Silky handcuffs the guy’s wrist to his ankle. So I stand this wino up when Silky’s not looking, and all of a sudden he’s coming at Silky like this-- Clady hops on one leg, jabbing with one arm. The room is

dialogues.speaker: CLADY
dialogues.text: --and he got a couple shots in! Clady pulls a CHECK from his jacket over the laughter.

dialogues.speaker: CLADY
dialogues.text: So for all your pain and suffering Silk, here’s a little cushion to go with that enormous pension you’re coming into. Wander whispers to Ludlow under the noise--

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: (re: Mody) What was he - getting your measurements? Ludlow flags a waiter, signalling for a drink.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: For what?  21.

dialogues.speaker: CLADY
dialogues.text: Hats off to Silky boys! ALL THE OFFICERS stand.

dialogues.speaker: ALL
dialogues.text: Hats off to Silky!

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: (to Ludlow) Your fucking coffin, that’s what.

dialogues.speaker: CLADY
dialogues.text: (the check) That’s from everybody in this room! The tables return to separate, boisterous conversation.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: Mody's had coffee with Internal Affairs twice this week. If he were a half-decent cop he’d know we had a trail on him.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: He’s coming after one of us? Clady sits down, including himself in the hushed conversa

dialogues.speaker: CLADY
dialogues.text: Look who’s joining the living.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: (re: Ludlow) Mody's getting in his ear.

dialogues.speaker: CLADY
dialogues.text: Stick and move Lud. (swigs a drink) He hear from Biggs?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Who’s Biggs?

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: Mody's contact in I.A.

dialogues.speaker: CLADY
dialogues.text: Biggs was dark-horse - pun intended - for the police commissioner nom. That is, until our friend here-- (Wander) --was tapped instead. Ludlow raises an eyebrow. Wander nods, confirming the new  22.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: ‘bout time.

dialogues.speaker: CLADY
dialogues.text: (re: Ludlow) This guy really has been sleepin’.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: Now, he’s gonna take his pound by eroding my best people. Ludlow looks at them - still playing catch up. BUS BOYS clear the plates around them.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: (low) He’s starting with you, Lud. Inside word is Mody's feeding you to him on a stick.

dialogues.speaker: CLADY
dialogues.text: Your Little Saigon shootout won’t help. Across the room, Mody sits quietly with THREE OTHER UNIFO He meets eyes with Ludlow, before looking away.

dialogues.speaker: CLADY
dialogues.text: But you’ll be fine. We’re digging our own dirt on the self-righteous son-of-a- bitch.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: Clady-- (let’s stay on track) All we need from you Lud, is just to keep on smiling. Alright? Ludlow produces an unnerving fake smile.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: I’m serious Lud.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: So what’s he doing here?

dialogues.speaker: CLADY
dialogues.text: Keeping up appearances. It’s what I’d do. Ludlow looks around for his waiter. Makes a move to get u

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: Whoa, whoa, whoa - what are you doing? You go anywhere near him your head’s ona spear.  23.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: I’m not gonna touch him. Where Wander’s aggravated, Clady’s amused.

dialogues.speaker: CLADY
dialogues.text: (’How about that?’ ) He’s not gonna touch him. (then) That’s your whole life right there Ludlow. If you ran about two degrees cooler you could’ve been in on some very big things.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: Alright, enough. Clady gets the hint, turning away.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: We’ve been here before, haven’t we? When the earth opened up on you? I took care of you then; I’m taking care of you now. Now goddamnit just...fall in for once. Ludlow absorbs it all. Then--

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: I was just gonna take a piss. After a beat, Wander relaxes--

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: You’re an asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ludlow lurks outside the men’s room. We HEAR a clinking s from his palm: VODKA MINIATURES rolling over each other. Before Ludlow, the UNIFORMED COPS - Mody the nearest - ar making a slow exit. Mody sees Ludlow waiting in the wings

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (mouths ) Black before blue. Mody reads ‘black’ and sees red. He approaches Ludlow--

dialogues.speaker: MODY
dialogues.text: What was that?  24.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: It’s a poem. For you. All the brother cops I ever knew, you’re the only one who was always black before blue.

dialogues.speaker: MODY
dialogues.text: Now what makes you say that? Ludlow checks the dining room; Wander’s not watching.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: You feeling left out Mody? You’re welcome to join us in all our plotting and scheming.

dialogues.speaker: MODY
dialogues.text: Oh, I’m quite sure I’m not.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: What do you think you know around here? You’re a bystander, Mody. You exclude yourself and then you say ‘I wasn’t invited. The bad white men left me out.’

dialogues.speaker: MODY
dialogues.text: You a Christian Ludlow?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (scoffs) Come again?

dialogues.speaker: MODY
dialogues.text: Do you believe in the sanctity of Christ?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Yeah, save me Mody. Mody extends his arm, blocking Ludlow’s exit.

dialogues.speaker: MODY
dialogues.text: Only you can do that for yourself.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: I guess there are no criminals, right? (‘I got it!’) That’s why you never make an arrest.

dialogues.speaker: MODY
dialogues.text: No one’s beyond salvation. Mody's really in his face now.  25.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Mody have you ever fired your weapon? No. That’s not ‘cause you’re a Christian. It’s ‘cause you’re an affirmative action cop with no interest in real police work. You leave the war zones to the rest of us, and that’s fine. Just don’t take it out on me. (eases past Mody) It’s not my fault there are Asians in Little Saigon. Or black people in Compton.

dialogues.speaker: MODY
dialogues.text: (too loud) Is it their fault your life is shit? Wander is now watching from a distance. Shoney and DeMill their way out, marvel gleefully at this public stab.

dialogues.speaker: MODY
dialogues.text: ‘Cause you sure as hell take it out on them. From the depths of his soul, Ludlow drags up a smile for Mody watches Ludlow off. Fear flashes amid rage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ludlow paces outside the door to dispatch...back and fort like a caged lion. Finally, he can’t help himself. He bursts into--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A row of BLACK and HISPANIC WOMEN, all eating lunch at th stations. Ludlow approaches a LARGE, PRIMPED BLACK WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Looking fine Jada.

dialogues.speaker: JADA
dialogues.text: Pssshhh, you so bad Tom Tom.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Say what’s the 20 on Gil Mody? Jada keys her headset with three-inch fingernails.  26.

dialogues.speaker: JADA
dialogues.text: 85-A. Mody, you have ears on? What’s your 20? After a beat, Mody's voice comes crackling back.

dialogues.speaker: MODY
dialogues.text: Imperial and Prairie, Jada - but I’m off. What’s up? She looks up at Ludlow, who makes a ‘forget about it’ mot

dialogues.speaker: JADA
dialogues.text: Sorry about that 85-A. False alarm. (then) Tom Tom what--? She turns to find Ludlow already off on his way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRIDLOCKED CARS seem to bend in the heat off the asphalt. Sunglasses on, Ludlow stays two cars behind a Seville up ahead... MODY'S CAR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ludlow waits in his car - intently rolling the VODKA MINIATURES on his knee. Across the street, Mody exits the bank, pushing a THICK ENVELOPE into his jacket as he returns to his car. Ludlow rolls out after Mody's Seville. INT. LUDLOW’S CAMARO - A SHORT TIME LATER Through Ludlow’s windshield, we see Mody turn RIGHT, into KOREAN GROCERY STORE. Ludlow cranks a LEFT, pulling into the parking lot of a decrepit mini-mall. He kills the engine, watching as Mody enters the store. Sweat seeps through Ludlow’s skin as he fixedly watches t storefront across the street... Without taking his eyes off the store, Ludlow slowly - al ritually - unscrews the lid of a vodka miniature. He puts to his lips, and this time...he DRINKS IT DOWN.  27. Galvanized, Ludlow pulls off his belt. He begins wrapping tightly around his right hand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hand tight at his side, Ludlow stalks across the street. pauses for a BROWN MONTE CARLO that rumbles past, pulling next to the Seville. Reaching the front door of the store, Ludlow glances back it’s just a flash - a frozen moment: TWO BLACK MALES - afros and expressionless yellow eyes. T driver makes a seemingly innocuous gesture, ‘scratching’ under his collar...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ludlow drifts to a halt a few steps inside. He stands - thunderstruck - as something invades his consciousness... The belt uncoils from his fist, dropping to the floor... He looks back at the Monte Carlo. The driver wasn’t scratching anything; he’s fastening a BULLET-PROOF VEST. The passenger readies a SUB-MACHINE GUN in his lap. Ludlow crouches, drawing his service revolver. He recedes into the store, rounding a corner in a swift run-walk. Down the aisle ahead, Mody shops...

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (hisses) Mody. When Mody turns - and sees Ludlow coming at him, service revolver in hand...

dialogues.speaker: MODY
dialogues.text: Ludlow... He swings his shopping basket, SLAMMING it in Ludlow’s fa like a bag of rocks. Ludlow - caught completely off-guard - goes smacking back into the shelves in an avalanche of dry goods.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Mody...é  28. But Mody is on him before he can rise, pistol-whipping hi with his gun back to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: What the fuck are you doing!? Mody stomps on Ludlow’s gun-hand and jams his .38 service revolver under Ludlow’s cheekbone.

dialogues.speaker: MODY
dialogues.text: Drop it!

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Are you fucking crazy!

dialogues.speaker: MODY
dialogues.text: Let it go! Mody's shaking. He’s going to shoot Ludlow point-blank - right here, right now - right in the face. The gun slips from Ludlow’s fingers.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Listen to me you fucking idiot - two silverbacks are about to roll in here hot! Mody yanks cuffs from his belt and snaps them onto Ludlow wrists.

dialogues.speaker: MODY
dialogues.text: And you just happened to be cruising by?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: This isn’t you and me-- But before Ludlow can finish, time GRINDS DOWN. At the en of the aisle, the TWO MEN FROM THE PARKING LOT... SUB-MACHINE GUNS in their hands. In a drawn-out second, Mody realizes that Ludlow was tell the truth. Then-- BOOM! TIME HOOKS again as one gunman shoots the GROCER po blank. The other aims down the aisle - at the detectives caught like feuding children... Mody STRUGGLES with his holster... Ludlow crawls for cove Mody an inadvertent SHIELD... as THUNDEROUS FIRE erupts. Still handcuffed, Ludlow fumbles with a key. He unlocks o wrist and immediately RETURNS FIRE down the aisle.  29. EVERYTHING AROUND HIM EXPLODES in reply. Ludlow tries to stay small, to weather the storm, when it all falls SILEN He waits coiled - heart pounding - for them to step aroun the corner and kill him. But the only thing that edges ro to him is a spreading POOL OF BLOOD. We HEAR the shooters exit hurriedly. Ludlow cranes around the corner, finding only Mody. He hurries to the fellow officer’s side... Mody's face is opened up. He breathes in bubbling gasps. Ludlow grasps Mody's hand...

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Mody - Jesus - stay with me man. I/’11 get help. I’m gonna get help. But Mody's hand tightens on Ludlow’s, not letting him go.

dialogues.speaker: MODY
dialogues.text: ---I thought... it’d be you... Mody's blood-sputtering breathing climaxes...then STOPS a

dialogues.speaker: VOICES
dialogues.text: Freeze! Ludlow looks up to find TWO UNIFORMED COPS. His bloody ha slips out of Mody's; he raises his arms...

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: I’m a cop. One of the wide-eyed cops pushes his partner’s gun down.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG COP
dialogues.text: Yeah... Ludlow. The other cop kneels to examine what’s left of Mody.

dialogues.speaker: OTHER COP
dialogues.text: Ho-lee shit. This one’s PD too.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG COP
dialogues.text: (to Ludlow) You just get here? You see anything? Cars skidding up outside. Silently, a million emotions racing through him, Ludlow gathers the HANDCUFF dangling his wrist up into his sleeve.  30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wander cuts through a buzzing crime-scene: POLICE OFFICER FORENSICS TECHNICIANS... Wander carries NONE of his affable nature this time. He spares a grim, cursory glance at the Korean grocer lying behind the counter. Near Mody's body, Shoney and DeMille are marking bullets. Wander lifts a plastic tarp on the ground, taking in the pit that was once Mody's face.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: Surveillance tape? DeMille nods toward a back office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ludlow sits sullenly, Clady staring down at him. Wander enters, closing the door behind him. A silence.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: How bad? Ludlow wordlessly hands him something from his pocket. A VIDEOTAPE. Wander weighs it a moment, then hands it to Clady. Wander’s sergeant puts it in the player... A GRAINY IMAGE of Mody idly shopping. Ludlow suddenly appears - gun at his side - moving quickl towards Mody. Mody cold-cocks him with the basket and tackles him.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: +--Jesus Ludlow... The SHOOTERS enter... They OPEN FIRE as Ludlow crawls and Mody falls. One of the gunmen scurries up to Mody, firing down on him point blank. Wander exchanges a LOOK with Clady, then ejects the tape.  31.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: It was a straight heist that went bad--

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: Don’t say anything yet. Wander looks to Clady, less emotional, for his take.

dialogues.speaker: CLADY
dialogues.text: Doesn’t matter what it was.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: It’s not what it looks like.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: That’s all there is, Lud! How it fucking looks. Now shut up for a second.

dialogues.speaker: CLADY
dialogues.text: (re: Ludlow) Well, he’s not a cop anymore. Ludlow reels.

dialogues.speaker: CLADY
dialogues.text: The wrong prosecutor sees this... Yeah, time. Big time.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: For what? Because Mody was in the wrong place at the wrong time--

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: No because you were! Who gives a shit about Mody? (then) Jesus Christ, you can never see two moves ahead, can you? You pulled two thugs off the street and went after a cop who was testifying against you. It writes itself. A KNOCK on the door. Clady opens it an inch - whispers DeMille away.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: This is a wet dream for Biggs.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (low) If I was gonna kill him I wouldn’t need two thugs.  32. Wander snaps, lunging at Ludlow and holding him by the ha The Lieutenant may be off the street, but he’s very stron

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: Is this who you are? Huh? You take a belt to another cop? Clady gets between them.

dialogues.speaker: CLADY
dialogues.text: Alright. Alright. We’re okay.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: How many times have I gone to bat for you? Every time! You think this is just about you? Wander turns away, embarrassed by his outburst.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: What do you want from me? I fucked up. You want my badge? You want me to do the time? I don’t fucking care.

dialogues.speaker: CLADY
dialogues.text: (calmly) Lud, you may not care how the rest of the world sees you, but you go down you stain all of us. This whole department... Speak up if you disagree. Ludlow stares at the floor like a schoolboy. Wander knead his brow, agonized.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: Anyone else see this tape?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: What difference does it make? Even without the tape the shooters put me in the store.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: Not if they never get picked up. Ludlow moves from confused...to astonished.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: (plainly) I want my new job, Lud. I know Clady’s not ready to work security... All I asked was that you stay away from him. (then) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WANDER (cont'd) You crossed me on this one, but you don’t deserve to go to jail for it. Letting Biggs throw you to the lions isn’t gonna bring Mody back. Wander checks with Clady before saying it...

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: This one’ll go to ‘Unsolveds.’ If you get a pass...they get one too.

dialogues.speaker: CLADY
dialogues.text: (nods; heavily) Unsolveds.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (sheepishly) I could take my chances with a jury.

dialogues.speaker: CLADY
dialogues.text: (amused) To the fucking lions.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: Justice is a live wire Lud. You wanna let go? Let the system work you? Or you wanna let us do our jobs? (candidly) This is what we do for our own Lud. You’re just usually home in bed at this point. In a dreamlike state, Ludlow finds himself nodding.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: Alright, we’re moving forward. Let’s get an acceptable account. All eyes on Clady; we’re in his world now.

dialogues.speaker: CLADY
dialogues.text: Mody was off duty, shopping. Two perps rolled in on a 211. Ludlow was first on scene - fellow officer was already down. Simple. No changes.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: (to Ludlow) Got that? (beyond disappointed) Bring your uniform tomorrow. Wander exits as Clady ejects the tape.  34.

dialogues.speaker: CLADY
dialogues.text: We would’ve busted Mody without you. Ludlow’s left alone with the video tape. After a life- changing beat, he rises...and POCKETS the tape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The morbid crime scene HUSHES as Ludlow emerges. He finds DeMille, who nods understandingly. Shoney opens the front door, leading Ludlow out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Megan steps out of the KCAL news van, searching for the u suspects through a host of ONLOOKERS. She locks eyes with Ludlow, sensing immediately that this crime scene is diff Ludlow turns away from Megan, finding DeMille waiting patiently, holding his car door. And Ludlow realizes, thi have changed with Shoney and DeMille...he’s one of them n Megan watches as he disappears - complicit - into the car INT. LUDLOW’S HOME - NIGHT Ludlow sits alone, chopsticks and empty takeout cartons b him. His windows are covered in HEAVY DRAPES, his sun-sta walls bare, save for WHITE PATCHES where pictures have be taken down. He watches a familiar face on his TV...

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: Two male suspects are wanted for the slaying of an off duty police officer tonight. The officer has been identified as Gilbert Mody, a 25 year veteran of the Los Angeles Police department. A source close to the investigation tells me exclusively that Mody was inside the Korean market behind me, when the suspects entered to rob it. (off her notes) Mody is survived by his wife Linda... and just from speaking to those on the scene, I can tell you that this is a loss not only to her, but to this entire community where Mody was very well-known and liked... (her notes again) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MEGAN (cont'd) Funeral services are expected to be held Friday at the Cathedral of Our Lady of the Angels... Ludlow mutes the television, staring blankly at Megan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO DESK SERGEANT’s stare curiously as Ludlow totes his uniform over his shoulder. They’ve never seen him before.

dialogues.speaker: DEEPER INTO THE STATION
dialogues.text: Ludlow walks crookedly - no sleep, and the weight of this world on his shoulders. He begins to be recognized by the ‘day shift’... Ludlow ignores the passing stares, heading into--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ludlow dresses at his locker, buttoning a dusty uniform. It’s been a long time. A PASSING OFFICER slaps him on the back. It’s meant amica but it’s just a tad too hard. Ludlow looks back curiously, then returns to his tie - tr to clip it on.

dialogues.speaker: 2ND PASSING OFFICER
dialogues.text: (low) Still the man. Now Ludlow turns around. He garners the attention of a FELLOW NIGHTWATCHMAN, who sits exhausted after a long nig

dialogues.speaker: FELLOW NIGHT WATCHMAN
dialogues.text: Attaboy Lud. They assume he has killed Mody - and he’s the toast of th As Ludlow closes his locker, something catches his eye... Down the line, a locker with MODY’S NAME... A BLACK LINE CROSSED THROUGH IT. Ludlow’s enjoying none of this. INT. WANDER’S OFFICE - A SHORT TIME LATER Wander’s on the phone, signing a gift basket that his SEC holds in front of him. He motions Ludlow in.  36.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: Well, listen, it’s a reminder isn’t it? My officers face that threat every day they put on the uniform. You just don’t write stories about it. Ludlow stands sheepishly - not sure if he should sit.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: Alright. I’11 be reading it. (hangs up; to Ludlow) Sit down. Sheila bring Tom some coffee. Ludlow cups himself - his silent protest - as he sits.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: How you doing? You sleep? (wryly) You’ve been getting me out of bed more and more these days... (then; heavily) We’re all seeing just a little too much of you Tom, for someone who’s supposed to work out of sight, out of mind... Nobody wants you in their living room. Christ, I don’t even wanna know half the things you do. Wander mutes his ringing telephone.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: Look, I’m not trying to give you another dose here. But I gotta bury you somewhere for a while. A nice, politically correct little spot.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: The fuck does that mean? Sheila stands stunned beside Ludlow, his coffee in her ha

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: You’re a doll Sheila. We’1l take that on the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ludlow looks even more uncomfortable, trailing Wander wit cup and saucer in his hands. They arrive at a SPARSE, DREARY OFFICE. The sign on the door: CIVILIAN COMPLAINTS INVESTIGATION.  37.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Anywhere else. I’m asking you as a friend.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: (amused) Look at it this way: it’s your first day of school and all the other kids already know you. Indeed, a HALF-DOZEN COMPLAINT INVESTIGATORS stare at Lud He’s well known here. A SUPERVISOR approaches.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Fuckin’ embarrassing.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISOR
dialogues.text: Lieutenant.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: He’s all yours. (whispers) It’s just temporary Lud. Ludlow hands off his coffee cup, being led away.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: Play nice now.

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTS LATER,
dialogues.text: The supervisor whizzes Ludlow past the gaping ‘desk jocke

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISOR
dialogues.text: --your job is to interview the complainants and do back-up interviews if you get two or more complaints against a given officer. The temptation is to be a good brother cop. Don’t be. Most of this shit’s not going anywhere anyway. Handle that? They arrive at a small desk.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Suppose I get a complaint against myself?

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISOR
dialogues.text: (without irony) Write it up and file it under standard guidelines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ludlow guzzles a coffee, waiting for his first complaint. His eyes drift to a poster on the wall: a LATIN OFFICER posing with ADMIRING CHILDREN. MAN’S VOICE Wake up, popo. Ludlow turns to find a YOUNG WHITE PUNK staring at him. He is the first in a string of COMPLAINANTS - all colors and creeds - but all lower middle class or impoverished. Ludlow uncaps his pen...takes a deep breath...

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: You have a complaint?

dialogues.speaker: WHITE PUNK
dialogues.text: Shoot I got multiple. Okay? Multiple complaints need addressin’.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK MAN
dialogues.text: Motherfucker looked like you. But black. Beat my ass like Rodney King. But there wasn’t no video.

dialogues.speaker: ASIAN WOMAN
dialogues.text: Pull me over for no reason!

dialogues.speaker: LATIN MAN
dialogues.text: Forced me out of my car, holmes.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK WOMAN
dialogues.text: Out of my house... Didn’t even care my children were there.

dialogues.speaker: WHITE PUNK
dialogues.text: My boys was right there, and they make me look like a bitch. Hold on Ludlow. He reaches into a drawer, grabs a BOX OF TISSUES and places it before the stunned punk.

dialogues.speaker: HISPANIC MAN
dialogues.text: (holding piece of paper) I know the law. But you don’t know that I know! Ludlow downs an Aspirin, making his ‘keep going’ gesture.  39.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER BLACK MAN
dialogues.text: Stop doing that. It’s an impertinent gesture and I’m not a suspect you’re grilling for information. (then) Now I assure you, if I was dealing drugs I’d have more than a hundred and twelve dollars on me. But they took it anyway. Saying it was ‘company money’ now. Ludlow stops. Actually looks at the complainant--

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: You get a badge number?

dialogues.speaker: OLDER BLACK MAN
dialogues.text: Well since his foot was on my throat, I missed it. But it wasn’t just the one guy. There was two or three of them, saying they gonna ‘take it home’. Ludlow digests a moment, then makes his ‘keep going’ gest

dialogues.speaker: HISPANIC MAN
dialogues.text: (ve: piece of paper) Look at it. You can see it right there. Behind the aggravated complainant, a DISTINGUISHED BLACK waits his turn.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: There’s nothing wrong with this warrant. The Hispanic man points to the crumpled page in Ludlow’s

dialogues.speaker: HISPANIC MAN
dialogues.text: It says they lookin’ for a gun!

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: And did they find a gun?

dialogues.speaker: HISPANIC MAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, but it don’t say nothing about no coke.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: They found some coke?

dialogues.speaker: HISPANIC MAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, but it ain’t on there. That warrant’s for a gun. Ludlow stares a disbelieving beat.  40.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Yeah, I see your point.

dialogues.speaker: HISPANIC MAN
dialogues.text: Yeah. Ludlow motions for him to get up--

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Yeah, lawyer up. See what you can do. The Hispanic man rises, not entirely sure of what’s happe

dialogues.speaker: HISPANIC MAN
dialogues.text: See what-- Yeah. Damn right I will. The distinguished black man (BIGGS) watches the complaina off, then sits calmly across from Ludlow. ANOTHER BLACK M waits at a distance, not unlike a bodyguard.

dialogues.speaker: BIGGS
dialogues.text: Say, aren’t you that cop I saw on TV?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Do you have a more specific complaint against me? Biggs, a well-kept 50, unbuttons his three piece suit.

dialogues.speaker: BIGGS
dialogues.text: Wander’s got a sense of humor, I’1l give him that. Took me all day to track you down. Ludlow’s suddenly alert.

dialogues.speaker: BIGGS
dialogues.text: (hand reaching out) Terrel Biggs.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Tom Ludlow.

dialogues.speaker: BIGGS
dialogues.text: Oh yes sir, I know. And me? D’you know me?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Sure, you’re the one Mody was snitching to. Biggs is visibly stunned.  41.

dialogues.speaker: BIGGS
dialogues.text: Now that is a hell of a thing to admit to knowing. Under the circumstances. Ludlow’s unmoved. He’s unreadable. Biggs recovers--

dialogues.speaker: BIGGS
dialogues.text: Alright, good for you. (bobbing like a boxer) You caught me with one there.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Mody tell you I’m just a racist atheist?

dialogues.speaker: BIGGS
dialogues.text: Hey, who isn’t these days? (then) You did work Firestone in the 90’s, though. ‘Phonebook Tom’. Ain’t that right?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Got my best confession with a ‘91 Directory. Biggs stares, like he’s seeing an animal up close for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: BIGGS
dialogues.text: Picked up a few complaints along the way, didn’t you? Ludlow stiffens - wondering if the ‘interview’ has begun.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Is this it?

dialogues.speaker: BIGGS
dialogues.text: This is just a back and forth.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (joylessly) Twenty-two complaints.

dialogues.speaker: BIGGS
dialogues.text: Twenty-three actually. Including the other night.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Well I got a few medals in between if we're counting.

dialogues.speaker: BIGGS
dialogues.text: Can’t have one without the other, can you? (off Ludlow) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BIGGS (cont'd) I know how it works, Tom. I know Wander was on duty for almost all those complaints when he worked the night watch. I noticed Clady was overseeing the other night. (off Ludlow) Friends in high places. Ludlow makes his bored, ‘keep going’ gesture.

dialogues.speaker: BIGGS
dialogues.text: Like I said, a back and forth Tom.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: I’m not much of a dancer, so if there’s something you’d like to ask me... Biggs stares intently, his edge suddenly breaking--

dialogues.speaker: BIGGS
dialogues.text: (jokingly) I just wanna know what you do those other nights? Ludlow cracks an ambiguous smile.

dialogues.speaker: BIGGS
dialogues.text: They give you a lunch break?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ludlow sits across from Biggs in a sparsely populated foo court. Neither seems hungry. The Internal Affairs man places a tape recorder on the ta pressing ‘RECORD’.

dialogues.speaker: BIGGS
dialogues.text: You were first respondent last night... Tom? Ludlow hesitates, eyeing Biggs’ ASSISTANT at a nearby tab

dialogues.speaker: BIGGS
dialogues.text: (ve: ‘the interview’) This is it. Then... Ludlow does it. He lies--

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Yeah.  43.

dialogues.speaker: BIGGS
dialogues.text: ‘Yeah’, you’re Tom Ludlow? Or ‘yeah’, you were first on scene.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Both.

dialogues.speaker: BIGGS
dialogues.text: Were you alcohol-impaired at the time of the shooting?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BIGGS
dialogues.text: So you could describe the shooters.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Height, weight - yeah.

dialogues.speaker: BIGGS
dialogues.text: Three men?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Two. Biggs looks irritated as TWO PLAYING CHILDREN storm past.

dialogues.speaker: BIGGS
dialogues.text: You a law and order man, Tom? Would that describe you?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: BIGGS
dialogues.text: But more order than law, right? What I mean is, Tom, at the end of the day it’s order that counts. Don’t sweat the details; break a few eggs to make an omelette; break a few bones to keep the public safe.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Whatever you say.

dialogues.speaker: BIGGS
dialogues.text: I guess what I’m saying Tom - what I’m asking - is if you and Wander keep tearing down the law to go after the devil...then what protects us when the devil comes after us?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Sounds a little above my pay grade.

dialogues.speaker: BIGGS
dialogues.text: That must be a real warm blanket for you. (then) Would you lose any sleep Tom, if I told you that not two, but three calibers of slugs were pulled from Mody's body? Ludlow gives nothing away.

dialogues.speaker: BIGGS
dialogues.text: To me that means there were three shooters. (then; soothingly) What were you doing there Tom?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: First respondent.

dialogues.speaker: BIGGS
dialogues.text: I spoke to the second respondents - two nice young boys. They say they were no more than two, three blocks away when they got the call. But you beat’em there... I wonder if our girl Jada in dispatch could explain that. Ludlow just stares at the churning recorder.

dialogues.speaker: BIGGS
dialogues.text: ‘Officer down’, that mean anything to you? Or does that change because it was Mody? Biggs grabs the recorder, angrily STOPPING it--

dialogues.speaker: BIGGS
dialogues.text: This bothering you Tom? ‘Cause I gotta tell yah, nobody seems too upset about the fact that two cop killers are walking around out there - living, laughing, fucking...

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (begrudgingly) Doesn’t change ‘cause it was Mody.

dialogues.speaker: BIGGS
dialogues.text: Then why don’t you go find the motherfuckers that did it!?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: It’s...not my decision.  45.

dialogues.speaker: BIGGS
dialogues.text: Whose is it? Ludlow’s mouth tightens; he walked right into this one.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Wander assigns the cases.

dialogues.speaker: BIGGS
dialogues.text: Well, I’m sure he’s got his best cop on this one. Detective-- (searching) --Diskant. Must be a hell of a cop if I’ve never heard of him. Anyway I’m sure he’1l find our two cop killers for us. Then maybe they can tell us who that third shooter was. Won’t that be just ace-crackerjack?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: That’d be great.

dialogues.speaker: BIGGS
dialogues.text: Fuck you! Where’s the tape from the store?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Was there one? Biggs gathers his recorder; this ‘interview’ is over.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: You haven’t seen the last of me. (off Biggs) That’s your line, right? I’m gonna take your badge and shove it--

dialogues.speaker: BIGGS
dialogues.text: You a little fish Ludlow. I’m a’ bait my hook with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ludlow stews at his desk...mulling Biggs’ words. A COMPLAINANT rambles in muted tones. Suddenly Ludlow ris simply walking away.  46.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still in his uniform, Ludlow hesitates - watching his fel detectives around their bullpens. All of them wear BLACK around their badges. Ludlow swallows his pride, wading forward... WHISPERS and CHUCKLES in his wake. Shoney and DeMille - the slick blac and white tandem - spot him.

dialogues.speaker: DEMILLE
dialogues.text: Oh, that is butch, Ludlow. As Ludlow heads for them, Shoney and DeMille rise for a f

dialogues.speaker: SHONEY
dialogues.text: You lost, boy?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (‘keep going’ motion) What’s the field breakdown on Mody? The homicide detectives exchange a disbelieving look.

dialogues.speaker: DEMILLE
dialogues.text: Told you he’s a piece of work. Go ahead, tell him.

dialogues.speaker: SHONEY
dialogues.text: (‘get this’) Diskant’s leading two teams on the suspects, one tip-chaser team, and one phone team.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Why Diskant? Why not you fucks?

dialogues.speaker: SHONEY
dialogues.text: Because we’d find they ass Ludlow. Then who’d be fucked? Ludlow is visibly repulsed by these men. Nearby, an observing DETECTIVE places a call - his eyes on Ludlow.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Well where is he?

dialogues.speaker: DEMILLE
dialogues.text: (giddily) He’s at his desk. Ludlow starts away--  47.

dialogues.speaker: DEMILLE
dialogues.text: You got a guardian angel trying to help you Ludlow. (pointedly) I’d let him. DISKANT’S DESK - MOMENTS LATER A FLOPPY-HAIRED DETECTIVE, early 30’s, sits amid organize chaos - PAPERS and PHOTOGRAPHS everywhere. Ludlow grabs a nearby chair, swinging it over to Diskant sitting heavily. Diskant looks back slowly, over his shou

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: You’re Paul Diskant.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Wander gave you the market shooting?

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: You know who I am?

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Well you think you might want to speak to me about it? Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: (nodding) You’re on my list. Ludlow turns his attention to Diskant’s desk. Indeed, he a LIST - it actually says ‘INTERVIEWS’ - next to a namepl and SEVERAL FILES and PHOTOS...MODY’S SHATTERED FACE AMON

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: You done this before?

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: In Portland, yeah. Ludlow almost loses it. ‘Portland’. He kneads his brow.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: How you doing so far?  48.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: I’m still trying to get my ducks ina row. Get a clear picture of things.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (sarcastically) But you definitely got a list. that we have. I mean,

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: What are you doing here Ludlow? Ludlow looks back; the other gawking detectives make no effort to turn away.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Well, not to rush your process, but I want a ballistics report. Diskant instinctively puts his hand over the report.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: What about it?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Two or three shooters? A beat.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: They pulled a third type of slug out of Mody's lung this morning. Diskant stares knowingly. He’s not as thick as Ludlow pre

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: What about forensics?

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: Too soon.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Is that what they told you? Diskant’s eyes give him away: ‘Yes.’ Ludlow sighs. He’s going to have to do this himself.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (leaving) Don’t get up. Diskant watches Ludlow off. Then - as if not wanting to m out - he follows.  49. INT. L.A. COUNTY CORONER’S - DAY A cold basement area - part lab, part storage. The CHIEF CORONER looks up from a body, staring at Ludlow through safety glasses.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (opening his badge) I work 77th--

dialogues.speaker: CORONER
dialogues.text: Tom Ludlow.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (calculating) Yeah, you know me?

dialogues.speaker: CORONER
dialogues.text: Sure. You were on TV the other night. (Ludlow relaxes) I recognized you from when your wife was brought in. Ludlow’s color fades. He focuses on the man.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: You did it?

dialogues.speaker: CORONER
dialogues.text: (pointing to table) Here... yeah.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (mantra-like) No foul play. Diskant suddenly enters, ‘booty wraps’ over his own shoes

dialogues.speaker: CORONER
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) Just an explosion in her head. I get one in here a week. They’re all different - - different places in the brain - but all the same I guess. Lights out. The coroner looks at Diskant: ‘booty wraps’ over his shoe

dialogues.speaker: CORONER
dialogues.text: You guys can’t be here.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: I’m with Diskant. He’s lead on the market shooting.  50.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: Wander knows we’re here. Ludlow looks at Diskant - a brief, trust-building second.

dialogues.speaker: CORONER
dialogues.text: (old boy’s club) What do you need Ludlow?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Is that Mody? Indeed it is Ludlow’s old ‘friend’ beneath the coroner.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Do you have three shooters? A pregnant beat.

dialogues.speaker: CORONER
dialogues.text: Nah. One of the suspects switched to a smaller, finishing side arm. That’s all. (then) Gimme another day I’1ll tell you if it was Fremont or Coates.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: Who’s that? The shooters?

dialogues.speaker: CORONER
dialogues.text: (skeptically; to Ludlow) You’re just walking him through the motions?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (re: Diskant) Yeah, he still wants to make it look good. (makes the ‘jack off’ sign) Turn over every stone. You got a lock or what?

dialogues.speaker: CORONER
dialogues.text: (nods ) Prints, hair, even a little blood. LaShawn Fremont and Wade Coates.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: What kind of history do they have?

dialogues.speaker: CORONER
dialogues.text: A bad one. Rape, narcotics...murder.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Lovely. What about robbery?  51. One too many questions.

dialogues.speaker: CORONER
dialogues.text: I gotta speak to Wander.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Call him. We’1ll wait right here. The Coroner retreats skeptically to a phone.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: We’re not waiting are we?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: No, we’re not. Ludlow grabs a PRINTOUT off a counter, exiting hurriedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ludlow walks ahead of Diskant down the dark, empty hall.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: Jesus. I can’t believe they I.D.’d them already--

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: What kind of deal you cut, Disco?

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: You trading up?

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? Without warning, Ludlow HITS Diskant in the stomach.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Cut the Bambi shit! You’re not solving this case! You know it’s closed--

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: I don’t-- Ludlow picks Diskant up, lodging his forearm into the you man’s windpipe.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Who came to you!? Who dealt you in?  52. Diskant’s eyes are coming out of his head.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: Don’t you know?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: (gasping) Clady. (Ludlow eases off) Clady. Diskant gasps for air; he’s really shook up. Ludlow’s flo with embarrassment, but still makes his ‘keep going’ gest

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: He said if I stepped up - took the loss on this one - I’d be included in bigger things. Ludlow deflates, exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: I was told I was doing you a favor.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: How does it work? You mail it in - let two cop killers walk on my account? You like me that much? Or are you that fuckin’ bent already?

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: I don’t know you. I don’t care about you or Mody; he was a rat piece of shit, wasn’t he? I care about my job.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Climbing before you can walk.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: Fuck you Ludlow. What about you? What are you doing here? All the shit you pulled, you get a sudden attack of conscience. You’re better than everybody else? (off Ludlow) You’re the worst one. Ludlow absorbs the blows. After a long, hard beat, he nod  53.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (sullenly) Yeah, I’m the worst. But there’s different kinds of bad, Disco...

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: (cynically) C’mon. You’re really gonna find these guys? Ruin your whole life over a cop nobody liked...who hated you worse than anyone?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: I just take complaints, Disco... You’re homicide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 21 RIFLES FIRE. They’re reloaded and FIRED AGAIN. A MOMENT OF SILENCE as Ludlow, dressed in a dark Jc Penny suit, surveys from the back of a STANDING GALLERY... Across on open grave - a flag-draped casket still above g a VEILED BLACK WOMAN sits amidst other women. Mody's wido The rifles FIRE AGAIN. Wander stands, head bowed before a microphone. Nearer to Ludlow, Diskant steals a glance at him through the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: DEMILLE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Just can’t let this dog lie, can you? Ludlow turns to find his favorite couple, Shoney and DeMi They whisper over Wander’s commencing eulogy--

dialogues.speaker: DEMILLE
dialogues.text: You know as dumb as you are, I’m probably just dumb enough myself to understand your motives.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (dryly) Explain them to me sometime. There’s a thread that keeps eluding me.

dialogues.speaker: DEMILLE
dialogues.text: You can’t stand being in debt. That’s why you got no friends. Somebody helps you out - you might have to look out for them someday. (then) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DEMILLE (cont'd) I don’t think you give a shit about Fremont and Coates.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (‘Does everybody know?) Jesus... What do you know about them? DeMille smiles wryly at Shoney.

dialogues.speaker: SHONEY
dialogues.text: Heroin caballeros. From Belize. Came up to make a sale and liked it so much they never left.

dialogues.speaker: DEMILLE
dialogues.text: We busted them ourselves a year ago. Rape-mutilation. Some black cooze on her way home from stenography class.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: They walked?

dialogues.speaker: SHONEY
dialogues.text: Bad bust. One of our own felt we had violated Mr. Coates and Mr. Fremont’s civil rights.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Did you?

dialogues.speaker: DEMILLE
dialogues.text: Of course we did. Ludlow blinks at them - realizing...

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Mody.

dialogues.speaker: SHONEY
dialogues.text: We'd hardly got them downtown before he started mouthing off about proper procedure.

dialogues.speaker: DEMILLE
dialogues.text: Before you could say ‘bullshit race card’ they were sprung. (disgusted) Didn’t even make it into the system.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (disbelieving) Mody sprung the shooters from the market.  55.

dialogues.speaker: DEMILLE
dialogues.text: They probably didn’t even register his face before they cracked it with a bullet.

dialogues.speaker: SHONEY
dialogues.text: Pretty ironic, isn’t it? He’d still be alive if it weren’t for all his Negro self-righteousness. Clady turns around angrily, silencing the threesome.

dialogues.speaker: DEMILLE
dialogues.text: (whispers) Why do you think Wander put Mody on poster duty? He was doing more to help crime than prevent it. Ludlow tunes them out now, his head swirling.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: (still at microphone) ..-from his time on the streets, to his time in your schools and homes. He was a tireless ambassador for the department, for his church, and for his family...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PHOTOGRAPHERS snap photos as Wander poses joylessly with CITY COUNCILMAN. Ludlow watches from a distance, drinking alone...reddish punch in a plastic cup. He absentmindedly sets the cup do at a crowded table, drawing STARES as he winds his way towards Wander. He’s cut off by Clady--

dialogues.speaker: CLADY
dialogues.text: Easy, big fella.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: I’m easy.

dialogues.speaker: CLADY
dialogues.text: Take it more easy.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: I’m fucking Chine-easy, Clady.

dialogues.speaker: CLADY
dialogues.text: Yeah, well... (looks back at Wander) -.-Not with the cameras.  56.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: I don’t want a damn picture with him.

dialogues.speaker: CLADY
dialogues.text: He doesn’t want a conversation either. Wander spots Ludlow, turning away coldly.

dialogues.speaker: CLADY
dialogues.text: (admiringly) Fucking Wander man. Look at all this. Donations are rolling in, public support’s through the roof. I don’t know what Mody's widow’s so upset about... First good thing her husband ever did. Ludlow scowls at Clady.

dialogues.speaker: CLADY
dialogues.text: (the scowl) Oooh, that’s good. I’1l take a picture with you. Watch this. Clady turns to the cameras, shaking his head in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: CLADY
dialogues.text: Terrible. So terrible. (back to Ludlow) You know, here we are, running around trying to close the doors on this thing for you... (re: Wander) You should’ve seen his face when he heard you were running around opening them up. (then) You don’t want to lose your last friend in him. Believe me.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Does he know these guys are wanted for more than just Mody?

dialogues.speaker: CLADY
dialogues.text: Of course he does. Everybody knows more than you Ludlow. Just assume that from now on.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Well I’m calling it off. This whole stand-down order--

dialogues.speaker: CLADY
dialogues.text: (hissing) You don’t call off shit! (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLADY (cont'd) You hear me? When you took your pass Fremont and Coates got theirs too.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Well I’m giving my pass back.

dialogues.speaker: CLADY
dialogues.text: No, no, no, no, no, no, no. If you wanted to play Christ-on-the-Cross you should’ve done it back in that grocery store. The second you took that tape it wasn’t just your own ass on the line. It’s every man in this department now. Ludlow looks about the room, OTHER COPS glancing his way. He finds Diskant, having a drink with Shoney and DeMille.

dialogues.speaker: CLADY
dialogues.text: Brothers in arms Lud. You meet with Biggs? (up close) We’ll assume it. ‘Cause he’s looking for any chink in the armor right now. Clady raises his glass as Ludlow retreats away...

dialogues.speaker: CLADY
dialogues.text: Don’t be that chink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ludlow walks heavily to his car, barely aware of his surroundings. No two ways about it... he’s torn. Nearby, a LIMOUSINE idles. Ludlow finds a procession of MOURNING BLACK WOMEN approaching. Linda Mody, beautifully poised, at the center. Wander watches, from a distance, as Ludlow sets himself i their path. The women part around him curiously, until Li

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Mrs. Mody? Linda considers him through her thin veil.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: I’m Tom Ludlow.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: I know who you are, Detective.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (startled) I was...first on scene.  58. She stares at him, in a way that makes him guess at first then reduces him to nothing.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: I wanted to say--

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: (smiling) I thought he had more friends. I should’ve spoken, but I couldn’t find one... Linda is absorbed by her waiting friends, then by the lim Ludlow stands gutted... ‘Lord, here comes the flood...’ INT. LUDLOW’S BEDROOM - NIGHT «---Guilt washes over Ludlow’s sweating features. He sits the stale, dark heat, watching the tape from the market. rewinds, over and over, as he drinks from a BOTTLE; no miniatures this time. ON HIS SMALL TELEVISION: Ludlow cowers behind a corner, trying to remove his cuffs. Then...he turns and FIRES dow the aisle...right over Mody. REWIND. He turns and FIRES down the aisle.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (the sound a gun makes) Pf£ffhhhooo. Ludlow lets it run, looking around his room for an escape Then, SOMETHING on the tape catches his welling eyes.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: What the...? He gets to within inches of the screen...mesmerized. Suddenly he EJECTS the tape...spooked. He reaches for his phone, holding it an indecisive beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Megan parks her car, spotting Ludlow lurking in the shado She won’t look at him as she approaches the front entranc She fumbles for the right key, feeling his eyes on her.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Thank you.  59.

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: I don’t wake up this time of night for non-sex. Ludlow simply smiles.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: You’re a delicate flower, Megan. She holds the door before opening it: ‘Do you want my hel

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: I’11l owe you one. Ludlow follows Megan inside.

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: Tell me why you can’t watch this at your own station?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: I’m not well-liked there.

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: Can’t imagine why not. She hits the button for the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: You punch somebody out?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Not really.

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: Accuse anyone new of sleeping with your wife?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: No, I exhausted that list. Megan steps into the elevator, turning back coyly.

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: So it’s just basically you they don’t like. Ludlow stares at her blankly.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (the elevator) I’ll get the next one.  60.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Megan works at an editing bay in the small room. Ludlow i perched expectantly before a large monitor.

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: Okay, where’s the tape? Ludlow watches her as she moves proficiently about the ro

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: I probably do owe you a....

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: I could probably take you somewhere to... (Megan waits) «+-apologize.

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: Yeah? Where’d you have in mind? An abandoned parking lot?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: I don’t mean like that--

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: It’s fine Lud. We’re on the same page. He can’t get near her tonight. She points over his should On the LARGE MONITOR: the surveillance tape from the mark Megan sits, slowly astonished by the soundless violence.

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: God. You can’t just tell me what happened?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Okay, right here. See this mirror? Move in on that or-- make it better. Megan tries to magnify the image.

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: I have people for this, you know? She brings up the MIRROR in a high corner of the store. O OF THE SHOOTERS can be seen in the reflection.  61.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Good, okay now run it. At half-speed, the SHOOTER appears to LIFT HIS STOCKING MASK...SPIT ON Mody...then SHOOT him at point blank.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (astonished) He spat on him.

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: So he...what? What does-- (dawning on her) He knew Mody. Ludlow nods, his fear confirmed.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Maybe. Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: So, it wasn’t a robbery?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: No...no, that would make it a hit. Ludlow suddenly heads for the VCR, past a dazed Megan.

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: He was snitching on you. Ludlow guiltily pockets the tape.

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: He was snitching all of you to some commission.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (nodding) I forgot who I was with for a second.

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: What did he have on you?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Nothing. Excessive force, racist plays.

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: That’s it?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: I’d know if there was more... I was just there to punch him in the mouth.  Time out. 62.

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: And you brought them to kill him.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Is that who you think I am? (then) I don’t know those guys, Megan. Mody knew them.

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: Okay, how?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Mody sprung them from a bust a year ago. Clady says he was dirty as all hell. Megan isn’t sure what to believe.

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: So... She makes his ‘keep going’ gesture.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Maybe they were in bed together.

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: What do you want me to do?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Nothing. If you can stand it.

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: What are you gonna do? Ludlow considers it a heavy beat. Then, as if surprised b his own conclusion--

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: I don’t believe that.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Well...you’re alone there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back in uniform, head sunk down, Ludlow manages a busy ha  63. He lifts his eyes, spying through a window to the DETECTI BULLPENS. Diskant is not at his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diskant stands defiantly at a tall counter.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: Yeah, Gil Mody... I got a bank statement here I’m trying to cross-reference. Was he carrying any cash when he came in? The CURATOR taps a few keys, reading from his screen--

dialogues.speaker: CURATOR
dialogues.text: Yeah - looks like... (eyebrows ) Ten grand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ludlow sits disconsolately at his desk. Maybe he is going let it go. Across from him sit TWO PROSTITUTES.

dialogues.speaker: PROSTITUTE
dialogues.text: This ass worked longer than all y’all cops disrespecting me--

dialogues.speaker: PROSTITUTE
dialogues.text: And they always do it on a motherfuckin’ Friday. So we don’t see no judge ‘til Tuesday and they know that ain’t fair... Ludlow stares at them - his mind elsewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diskant completes a circle around Mody's SEVILLE. He rifl through the glove box and console, then pops the trunk... It’s empty, aside from a jack and a spare. About to close the trunk, he spots a SMALL TAG attached to a torn string

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ludlow is mid-conversation with a PERSIAN MAN in jacket a

dialogues.speaker: PERSIAN MAN
dialogues.text: I said please, tell me what I am being charged with. But they just laugh. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PERSIAN MAN (cont'd) They took only - maybe - a hundred dollars, but that’s a lot of money back then... Then I see this picture of this retiring captain. The man shows Ludlow a NEWSPAPER PHOTO of SILKY (the reti officer from the Pacific Dining Car send-off).

dialogues.speaker: PERSIAN MAN
dialogues.text: This is the man who says it was company money now. That they couldn’t trust me with what I would spend it on--

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Back up. ‘Company money’, say what... Ludlow puts down a doughnut. Makes his ‘keep going’ gestu

dialogues.speaker: PERSIAN MAN
dialogues.text: Contribution to his corporation. (then) I don’t want my money back. But it stayed with me, you understand? I am third generation American, officer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An IMPOUND TECH across the counter examines Diskant’s TAG

dialogues.speaker: IMPOUND TECH
dialogues.text: Yeah, it’s an evidence tag.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: One of ours?

dialogues.speaker: IMPOUND TECH
dialogues.text: It’s got our coding prefix. He types the numbers into his computer, his brow furrowin

dialogues.speaker: IMPOUND TECH
dialogues.text: Weird... Hold on a sec. He disappears into the stacks. Diskant turns the screen t read it: ‘HEROIN - 3.255 Kilos.’

dialogues.speaker: IMPOUND TECH, (0O.S.)
dialogues.text: Funny... Diskant quickly turns the screen back as the Tech returns

dialogues.speaker: IMPOUND TECH
dialogues.text: The article’s in its place and properly tagged.  65. He picks up and re-examines the tag.

dialogues.speaker: IMPOUND TECH
dialogues.text: Wonder where the hell this came from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ludlow looks up from the NEWSPAPER CLIPPING of Silky. He looks the Persian man squarely in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: I’m sorry that happened to you. The man exhales, a weight lifted.

dialogues.speaker: PERSIAN MAN
dialogues.text: Thank you. And that’s enough for him. He leaves Ludlow with his thou On his way out, the Persian man passes Diskant - waiting purposefully. Diskant locks eyes with Ludlow, then walks

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ludlow sticks his head into the hall. Down the way, Diska lets Ludlow spot him, then heads into the MEN’S ROOM. INT. MEN’S ROOM - MOMENTS LATER Ludlow opens the door hesitantly. He finds it empty, save for an edgy Diskant.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: This is the faggiest thing I’ve ever seen. Diskant stands his ground.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: Homophobe. Good to know on top of everything else.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: You getting it from all sides on this?  66.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (sighs; reluctantly) No worse than you, choir boy. Diskant glimpses himself in the mirror, a reckoning insta

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: Alright listen: I’m not saying I’m doing anything - or if I tell you one thing I’m gonna tell you anything else again... but I think I know what they had on Mody. Ludlow looks back at the door.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Go take a piss. Diskant reluctantly obliges, facing a urinal in case some enters. Ludlow moves to the sink.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Why do you say that?

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: First of all he had ten large on his person when he died. I checked out his car at impound; he had almost four kilos of ‘H’ in his trunk. Ludlow takes a moment, as if soaking it all in... Then--

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (xe: urinal) You put your whole body in it like that? Diskant moves back, irritated.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: Look, if I’m keeping you from your new job--

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Alright, so you found some ‘H’. So what?

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: So you still have a professional curiosity in Fremont and Coates? Ludlow makes his ‘keep going’ gesture.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: What do you think they do when they’re not raping and robbing?  67.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: They deal heroin. Ludlow nods slightly; he gets the point.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: And now you wanna shake some trees. Meet our terrible twosome. Diskant nods begrudgingly. Not how he would’ve put it.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Listen, Disco. There’s no shame if you wanna play ball with Clady. Get in on some of those big things.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: No shame if you wanna take your pass. Ludlow sizes up Diskant. Maybe he could go to war with th kid.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: It’s your career.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: It’s your funeral. Ludlow can’t help smirking at the volley. He thinks hard. Last chance to be smart.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Alright, let’s work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ludlow’s Camaro rolls - windows down, stereo pumping - in the hood. Diskant rides shotgun, second-guessing this who thing. They cross under a sign: CENTURY BOULEVARD. Ludlow - out uniform now - kills the music.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: So you’re not exactly the inside man here Disco, but you ever hear other cops talk about ‘The Company’? Their corporation or some shit.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: What, like investment funds?  68.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: No, like Serpico, shakedown funds.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: (disdainfully) Not interested.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: I’m not fucking offering dummy, I’m asking if you’ve heard of it.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: No, never have. But I wasn’t around for the good old Rampart days. (then) Why?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Just a complaint I’m following up on. Diskant peeks at Ludlow; this guy takes his job seriously

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Anyway quit congratulating yourself. You would’ve loved the old days. We were fucking kings... Just a few bad seeds that ruined it. As Ludlow brakes at a red light, a DEEP STEREO BASS begin rattle behind them. Without looking, Ludlow places his 9M under his thigh. After a beat, Diskant subtly follows suit, placing a larg -45 under his leg. Just then a LOUD CREW OF BLOODS pulls up. They’re ready t tear into Ludlow -- “This white boy is lost” -- until the see which white boy it is. Ludlow stares back at the silenced young men, until - one one - they reluctantly look straight ahead.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (the .45) The fuck is that?

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: Too much for you?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (exasperated) Almost every shooting is within ten feet, Disco. That’s gonna go right through somebody.  69.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: -..Guess I’m more humane than you. Ludlow turns back to the spooked Bloods--

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Green light. The driver reactively hits the gas, then brakes hard as h sees the light is still red. In the middle of the intersection - no one else around - the young men bicker each other: “Go! Just go Nigga”... Ludlow turns amicably to Diskant, really amused. Diskant shares none of Ludlow’s joy. Spurned, Ludlow mutters something to himself, driving on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THREE HISPANIC TEENAGERS lounge against their car, on the Meager bit of turf. Ludlow slows, half a block away.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Alright Disco. Your show.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: My show what?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Gotta start somewhere. Go ask’em where Fremont and Coates are hiding. The three teens SCATTER as Ludlow pulls up. Diskant jumps out, chasing one down the street. Ludlow drives calmly beside Diskant, enjoying the chase. The Hispanic ‘RUNNER’ cuts through a

dialogues.speaker: BASEBALL DIAMOND,
dialogues.text: prompting Ludlow to floor it onto the field. He spins aro the Runner, causing a CLOUD of DUST as Diskant finally ma the TACKLE. The young detective wrestles the young runner into handcuffs. Ludlow, meanwhile, calmly CRANKS THE HEAT on his dash.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: (to teen) Stop fucking moving! The more you move the more it hurts.  70. Diskant gets the dealer up on his feet.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: You gonna relax, or you gonna act like a little bitch?

dialogues.speaker: HISPANIC TEEN
dialogues.text: Fuck you tira.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: Fuck me?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Jeez Disco. Don’t you think that’s a little much? (off Diskant) Let’s just everybody cool out for a second alright? Ludlow takes the young dealer by the arm.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Listen, I don’t know what his problem is. You just sit down for a second, lemme talk to him, okay hermano? The dealer nods slightly as Ludlow sits him in his Camaro buckling him in before he can react to the SHOOTING HEAT. Ludlow slams the door shut. Diskant watches - stunned but not surprised - as the young dealer sweats, squirms...beg to SCREAM. Ludlow joins Diskant a quiet beat. Then--

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: You married Disco?

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: (distractedly) F...Fiancée.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: When’s the big day?

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: Ah, two summers.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (amused) Don’t rush into it now.  71.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: Nah, she wants a big one, so I’m trying to save for it...not easy. As if an oven timer has rung, Ludlow returns to his car, opening the door--

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Heroin! Who do I talk to after you?

dialogues.speaker: HISPANIC TEEN
dialogues.text: (gasping) The Grill, holmes. Talk to Grill. He post at MLK and Fig. Ludlow turns to Diskant, slapping a hand to his cheek in surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRILL, a young black male, kicks it with a BUDDY and a si pack on his tricked-out ‘64 Impala.

dialogues.speaker: GRILL
dialogues.text: Aw, hell no. Ludlow approaches with Diskant in tow.

dialogues.speaker: GRILL
dialogues.text: Shouldn’t you be sleeping in a coffin or some shit?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: You’re easy to spot in the day, Grill. Grill exchanges a look with his buddy, even with Diskant.

dialogues.speaker: GRILL
dialogues.text: Nigga what?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Great catching up. Listen, you have something; we need it; you’re gonna give it to us. Grill slides off his cherished Impala.

dialogues.speaker: GRILL
dialogues.text: Or what Ludlow? You gonna roust me? Pelican Bay? Lompoc? He holds his wrists out for handcuffing.  72.

dialogues.speaker: GRILL
dialogues.text: Party for me, White. Southside Crips - that’s my homies up in there.

dialogues.speaker: HIS BUDDY
dialogues.text: Hey yo - I go with him? They laugh together.

dialogues.speaker: GRILL
dialogues.text: See that? He traces a long scar running down his face.

dialogues.speaker: GRILL
dialogues.text: Check the grill. He pulls down his lower lip: no teeth.

dialogues.speaker: GRILL
dialogues.text: You know I seen John Wayne badass piggas like you before. And I tell those motherfuckers the same thing I tell you. (leans forward) Sum motherfucking total of nothing. (easy) Your move, White. BAM! Diskant kicks in the Impala’s shiny door.

dialogues.speaker: GRILL
dialogues.text: Nigga what the fuck! I just got that motha fucka motha fucking painted! Diskant looks to Ludlow, then KICKS it again.

dialogues.speaker: GRILL
dialogues.text: Aw hell no! Ludlow blocks Grill, as Diskant raises his arms tauntingl crazily - beyond.

dialogues.speaker: GRILL
dialogues.text: You ain’t gotta be kicking my shit like that! (to Ludlow) What you want!? Maybe I got it! Ludlow’s almost annoyed that it’s Diskant who has cracked

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Don’t tell me, tell Mr. Wayne.  73.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: Fremont and Coates.

dialogues.speaker: GRILL
dialogues.text: Fremont and Coat-- (searching) Okay, yeah, yeah I know them cats--

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: He’s not gonna touch your car again.

dialogues.speaker: GRILL
dialogues.text: (honestly) Never fucking heard of them.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: But you have heard of heroin, right? I mean, you do sell it in the L.A. Unified School District, don’t you? Ludlow puts a KEY in the Impala’s trunk... Grill looks do at his chain, realizing Ludlow has ‘picked’ him.

dialogues.speaker: GRILL
dialogues.text: Look, yo, heroin’s run out of Lompoc. How I s’posed to help you if I ain’t in Lompoc? Grill immediately regrets saying it. Ludlow’s eyes light

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (cheshire grin) Party for you, right? All your homies in there.

dialogues.speaker: GRILL
dialogues.text: No, no I didn’t say that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ludlow walks Grill a half-step ahead of him, through the of the prison. Diskant follows down the dark hall, into-- A HOLDING AREA. INMATES on both sides, as a DEPUTY WARDEN leads our three on. HISSES and GRUMBLINGS from both sides as the Deputy Warden raps on a metal door. GIANT’S VOICE Yo Ludlow! That you? That you boy?  74. The stalled threesome - Ludlow, Diskant, Grill - turn to a 6’6’, 280 pound SKINHEAD straining against his bars.

dialogues.speaker: SKINHEAD
dialogues.text: What, you can’t say hello? You don’t know me now? Look at me you fuck! Turn your back on me?! I will fucking end you!!

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY WARDEN
dialogues.text: Shut your hole! Shut it!! Grill, more than a little irked, looks up at Ludlow.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (straight ahead) I got homies in here too. The METAL DOOR clanks open to-- A VAST ROWS of CELLS - stories of them - and a WAITING GU Our men step through...

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: How you doing?

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Good, how you doing?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (ve: Grill) Our boy here’s gonna set up shop tonight. Take a few visitors, ask a few questions for me. The guard nods knowingly. Diskant watches as Ludlow palms FEW BILLS, passing them to the guard...just the way it is

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Alright Grill, you scan your homie database. Somebody knows Fremont and Coates, we’ll help that somebody out. Maybe a knock a year off, depending. Got it?

dialogues.speaker: GRILL
dialogues.text: Yeah. Cool. Diskant and Ludlow watch Grill off... Then, out of the bl

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Wanna get some dinner?

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: Ah, I should be getting back--  75.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: I’m messing with you Disco. Get home to that pretty wife. On Diskant - knowing it was a genuine invitation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sea of long desks, LAW STUDENTS beneath reading lamps. AMIDST the younger crowd, LINDA Mody sits before a half-d open books.

dialogues.speaker: LIBRARIAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No food or drink, sir. Linda looks up, spotting Ludlow at the far end of the lon hall. He’s eating his dinner - a crummy sandwich - and staring up at the cavernous ceiling. Linda looks panicked as Ludlow discards the sandwich. He wades forward, sifting through the FACES. Something about aging law enforcer among youthful law students. Finally, he SPOTS Linda, approaching cautiously. He grabs a nearby chair; it SCREECHES across the floor. Ludlow wai until the surrounding stares fade. Then, over a fragile p

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (continuing where he left off) I wanted to say that...I’m sorry this happened to you.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: How did you know I was here?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Your next-door neighbor. Linda looks about the crowded room, beyond uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: So this is where lawyers come from.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: So now you’ve said it. Ludlow gives up on levity.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: I didn’t speak either... At my wife’s funeral--  76.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: I know where you meant. (a beat) He spoke of you often.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: All good I hope.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Was there something else?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: .~+-Yeah, I guess there is. I wanted to tell you that, even if nobody else will... I’m going to find the men that killed your husband. A nearby student’s head snaps up. Linda bolts for the exi Ludlow’s look says it all: ‘that may have been a little a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ludlow emerges glumly into a dim courtyard. Linda surpris him, standing off to the side.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: What are you apologizing for?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: I’m not apologizing. I’m condoling. Ludlow thinks of moving to her. Thinks again.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Because...I was the first one there.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: So what did you see?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: That’s not gonna make you feel any better--

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Don’t you be familiar with me. I’m not joining your club because I lost Gilbert. (then) I was on the Sheriff’s for nine years - I can handle the details.  77. The CAMPUS NIGHT WATCHMAN - maybe 19 years old - shines h flashlight on the quarreling pair.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPUS NIGHT WATCHMAN
dialogues.text: Everything alright here? Ludlow looks ready to snap the youngster in two.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: We’re fine. Left alone again, Linda’s placid exterior cracks.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: I’m sorry for your loss. I am. But God took your wife... Who made Gilbert’s plan? (bitterly) Or was it just bad luck? Linda can’t sense the storm she’s brewing in Ludlow.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Loss is loss detective. Not knowing is a whole different thing. Ludlow moves close. He’s not going to harm her, but she’s going to listen.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: My wife had a...thing. She was born with it in her brain, and she was with someone when it finally burst. He put her on the curb at Cedar Sinai, and he drove away. (nods firmly) It’s in the not knowing... And I don’t care who’s plan it was. Linda holds his stare.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: So what did you see? She asked for it.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
