dialogues.text: It wasn’t an accident. They knew him somehow and they shot him in the face. They’re heroin dealers and I think they were in business with your husband. He was found with 10,000 in cash when he died. (then) Anyway, I can try to keep all of this from coming out.  78.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: (sarcastically) All for us? Gilbert must’ve really had you wrong. Ludlow just stares, tight-lipped. To hell with this.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: How many people knew he was talking to Internal Affairs?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: It wasn’t a well-kept secret. Linda lets her insinuation - indeed accusation - sink in.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: In my experience, detective, there are those who find the truth and those who lead it where they want it to go. (off Ludlow) I hope Gilbert was wrong about you...but your eyes just don’t look clear enough to me.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: They’re clear.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Gilbert was a third-rate street cop. I can admit that and it doesn’t mean I love him any less. But he wasn’t dirty. I asked him to be better and it made hima pariah. That’s what I would’ve said if I had spoken. (heated) He wasn’t stupid either. He knew his career would be over after testifying against all of you. We were going to leave Friday to live in the Bahamas... Silly of us, wasn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: You’re saying that’s what the money was for? Linda backs away.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: I’m saying that funeral wasn’t for him and you’re not here for us now. I think you’re here to find out how much I know. And you know what? He was so afraid of you he didn’t tell me a thing.  79. Ludlow watches her off, chewing on that.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (low) Night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back in his blues, Ludlow pulls a FILE from a tall, dusty stack. He looks up suddenly when he hears a NOISE-- MAN’S VOICE Somebody down here? Ludlow thinks a moment.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: I am. MAN’S VOICE Well who the hell’s that?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Ludlow. An ELDERLY OFFICER appears at the end of the row.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: Oh, well...hey. What are you...?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: I’m looking for Silky’s old reports. We’re throwing him a private retirement party and I’m putting together a gag reel for him. The officer laughs and shakes his head like “Ain’t that a pisser?”

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: Well he’s too old for the computerized stuff. You gotta look at the carbon files.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clady ambles down the hall, peeking furtively in on Ludlo right where he should be, at his desk. Ludlow looks up, receiving a big ‘THUMBS UP’ from Clady; stout sergeant is still really enjoying himself.  80. Ludlow returns to a FILE beneath him. A log entry reads: BAR VIOLATIONS/1993. Officers Clady, Harnish, Collinson, Ludlow stops on Mody - his name right there with Clady’s. INT. HALLWAY, OUTSIDE WANDER’S OFFICE - MOMENTS LATER Ludlow walks purposefully for Wander’s office, FILE in ha Ludlow Wander Taking away. Ludlow

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: No, we got a toe hold, Disco. But a toe hold’s better than no hold. Just wait for me there. stops himself at the last moment from barging in on and Biggs. The I.A. man stands over Wander’s desk. an earful, Wander SEES Ludlow but doesn’t give him Ludlow slinks off gratefully.

dialogues.speaker: CLADY
dialogues.text: Help you Lud? turns to find Clady on his heels.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Naw, you help me enough Clady.

dialogues.speaker: CLADY
dialogues.text: (re: Wander) He’s taking a beating for you in there. Standing by your bullshit, ‘first respondent’ story. (close to Ludlow) See they both know it was your bullet Lud. The third round in Mody. I’d say that puts you there for a jury, wouldn’t you?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: No. No, the M.E. said one of them--

dialogues.speaker: CLADY
dialogues.text: C’mon Lud. You got the tape. You know they didn’t pull a third gun. (then) I told you, we’re trying to help you. Ludlow swallows, his color fading.

dialogues.speaker: CLADY
dialogues.text: Now I’m not saying you killed him, but you didn’t help him Lud. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: sl. CLADY (cont'd) And they’1l get you for it. They’1ll get you on the drinking. They’ll take it all from you... Let this thing go. For your own good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ludlow walks slowly to his car, unbuttoning his uniform. Shoney and DeMille are just arriving for the night shift-

dialogues.speaker: DEMILLE
dialogues.text: Yo Ludlow! How’s complaints?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Your wife stopped by today. Shoney laughs. DeMille does not. Ludlow gets into his car starts it. Then, after a beat - stops it. He stares through his dusty windshield...torn apart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s dinner at sunset for Diskant. He stands alone at a h table, looking about the Barrio for any sign of his partn

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey golden boy. Ludlow bites into a burrito, perfectly at home in this Mexican enclave. Diskant looks relieved to see him.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: Where you been?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: No rush. I’m here. Diskant sizes up Ludlow... good enough.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: So what are we waiting on?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (mid-chew) Address.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: Fremont and Coates?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: An associate, apparently.  82.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: And you left Grill in there?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (mock disgust) I’m not gonna let him walk until it checks out, Paul. Diskant looks about, a little uneasy.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: Quit with the golden boy shit.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Well you are, aren’t you? You’re Clady’s protégé.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: You worried about Clady?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: No, I think I’m worried about you, choir boy. How do I know you’re not reporting up the ladder on us?

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: (sighs) I got more to lose than I can stand here, Tom. But you go ahead and sucker me again, ‘cause I don’t think ‘trust me’ is gonna do it for you. It’s not much, but it’s Ludlow’s kind of speak.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (satisfied) Ask me how’s complaints?

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: How’s complaints? Ludlow readies his ‘Your wife stopped by’... Then let’s i

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: So I’m checking a complaint on Silky; poor guy retires so they put his picture in the paper. Now he’s got everybody coming out of the woodwork on him. (then) Ask me who came up together under him. Diskant makes Ludlow’s ‘keep going’ gesture.  83.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Clady and Mody. They’re written up together three times.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: So...what? So Clady might have been involved in Mody's...

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Not what it could mean, Disco. What does it mean right now.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: Means Mody wasn’t always on the outside. Ludlow nods proudly.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: He was testifying about something. Maybe he actually had something.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: Okay, what?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Mody's widow said he was going after ‘all of us.’ Whatever that means.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: You spoke to his widow?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (stream of consciousness) Something big. Organized. Unionized.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: Like a corporation? DOTS. ..CONNECTING.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Were you at Silky’s retirement? (Diskant nods) So you saw that check Clady pulled out. Where’s that come from? I didn’t chip in. Did you? I know it’s not coming out of Clady’s pocket. Diskant caves in, absorbing the implications.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: I was having more fun a second ago.  84.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Relax, those are just ‘could be’s’. Ludlow reads his BEEPING PAGER, already on the move.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Yo, ho, ho. Toe holds, Disco.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: Address?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (’could be worse’) Plate. INT. LUDLOW’S CAMARO - A SHORT TIME LATER Ludlow guns it through a hole in traffic. Diskant’s shotg

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW, (INTO RADIO)
dialogues.text: Alright, I’m southbound, just crossed Imperial. Where’re you? COP’S VOICE (FROM RADIO) Well, you should see me. I’m three cars back of a maroon Cadillac. Owner: Cedric ‘Scribble’ Rose.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (to Diskant) That’s our guy. (into radio; jokingly) He hasn’t sold any heroin since you’ve been on him...? COP’S VOICE Not as far as I can tell.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW, (INTO RADIO)
dialogues.text: Alright, I see you. Peel off - nice work. The black and white turns away, leaving the maroon Cadill exposed. Diskant readies a POWERFUL RED SPOTLIGHT.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: I’m gonna pull him over.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: For what?  85.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: Are you serious?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Just wait. Let him roll through this stop sign. Both men watch as the driver - amazingly - makes a comple

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Okaaay... Did he signal?

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: (‘as a matter of fact’) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Alright, take it easy. What’s on his rearview? (excitedly) Are those dice? Ludlow’s saved by a voice from his radio-- WOMAN ’S VOICE Attention 41 A. California license Robert, Tom, Victor, 101, comes back with a failure to appear out of Glendale.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Eeww, that’1l do. Diskant FIRES the spotlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The driver, unseen for now, watches Diskant and Ludlow in side mirror. Both detectives approach with weapons drawn.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: Hands on the fucking wheel! Diskant comes face to face with a MASSIVE, SNIFFLING, 40 OLD BLACK MAN... This is SCRIBBLE. Diskant signals over t car to Ludlow: ‘Check his eyes’.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ludlow drops startlingly into the passenger seat--

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: What’up Scribble!? Scribble stares at Ludlow through shrunken pupils.  86.

dialogues.speaker: SCRIBBLE
dialogues.text: What you want with me?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: With you? Nothin’ man. You’re just a middle rung on a shitty ladder we’re climbing. But you missed a court date Scribble. That means we’re all gonna spend the weekend together... What else that mean, Disco?

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: Means he’s gonna pop his trunk. Scribble begins to tear up like a baby.

dialogues.speaker: SCRIBBLE
dialogues.text: What ladder?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Fremont and Coates. And we had to pay out for you Scribble, so don’t be cheap with us. Scribble weighs two terrible options.

dialogues.speaker: SCRIBBLE
dialogues.text: ---I ain’t seen them in a week. Nobody heard from them.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: How long you work with them?

dialogues.speaker: SCRIBBLE
dialogues.text: About three months. They dumped my supplier, took over his client list.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: You don’t have a number?

dialogues.speaker: SCRIBBLE
dialogues.text: Naw, man. Motherfuckers call me. Ludlow takes a moment, cleans his teeth with his tongue.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: You sniff your own glue, Scribble? Huh? You using? Scribble turns away.  87.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: You know what today is? Today’s fried-day. That means you’re not gonna see a judge ‘til Monday - Tuesday. You’re gonna get sick without your dope, Scribble. You don’t wanna get sick, do you?

dialogues.speaker: SCRIBBLE
dialogues.text: I help you, they kill my ass.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: Nobody’s killing your ass Scribble. We’re not even gonna bust them.. Scribble looks up at Diskant through the driver side wind

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: We just want a piece of the action teddy bear.

dialogues.speaker: SCRIBBLE
dialogues.text: (deep breaths) I picked up from them once...out in Palmdale. Little cinderblock place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An undeveloped stretch, apart from a solitary CINDERBLOCK HOME. A long stretch of desert extends behind it. 9MM drawn, Ludlow cases the front of the house. Diskant appears from around the back: ‘No sign of anyone.’ Ludlow throws a rock at the door. No response from inside He throws another rock through a window. No response. He kicks a loose section of the window glass, entering the DRUG SHACK. The place is RANSACKED - the fridge open, cushions sliced open...even a section of wall torn open. Diskant surveys the wall - good place for a stash - as Lu is drawn out the back door... A BLOODY DRAG MARK - feebly scrubbed - on the concrete pa It ends where the sand begins. Ludlow puts his nose in th air... a SICKENING WAFT leads him to-- THICK OLEANDER BUSHES behind the shack. BUGS SWARM above clump of shrubs. Beneath the swarm, Ludlow finds a horde RED ANTS around a hole in the sand...  88. Ludlow kicks at the ants, scattering them and revealing-- TWO DECAYED HEADS, bound in duct tape like mummies.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Disco! (then) Get a shovel!

dialogues.speaker: A SHORT TIME LATER
dialogues.text: Diskant coughs as he works a SHOVEL into the ground. He steps aside as Ludlow pulls out the SECOND PUTRID BODY. They run their flashlights up and down the corpses. Whoev they were, they’ve been dead at least several months.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: Fremont and Coates’ competition? Ludlow shrugs, his hands are covered in HUMAN MUSH.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: That might be asking a little much from Scribble.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: So what now?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: I got a deputy coroner owes me a favor. Let’s get’em I.D.’d.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: You know a certified M.E. who’ll bag and freeze two decomps?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: From the good old days.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: Must owe you a hell of a favor.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (smiling) I caught him going down on a foxy little cadaver. Diskant starts to laugh, but the smell sends him dry-heav  89.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ludlow raps on the hood of his Camaro. All 300 handcuffed pounds of Scribble shift in Ludlow’s tiny backseat.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Nobody here Scribble! Scribble’s head comes up slowly from his hiding place.

dialogues.speaker: SCRIBBLE
dialogues.text: I told yo ass they wouldn’t be.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Cut the jive and listen. Fremont and Coates call you again - you set up a meet for us. Face to face.

dialogues.speaker: SCRIBBLE
dialogues.text: You crazy White? You might’s well have Vice tattooed on your forehead.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (smiles) You just tell them I can do for them what Mody can’t anymore. You got that? Mody. They’11 know what you mean. Scribble nods reluctantly.

dialogues.speaker: SCRIBBLE
dialogues.text: Can’t we all just go home, now? INT. WANDER’S HOME - NIGHT Wander descends moonlit stairs. KNOCKING at his front doo He fastens his robe - dragged out of bed apparently - as ANOTHER LOUD KNOCK annoys him. He opens the door to find-

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: Jesus, Lud. I don’t work the night anymore. Ludlow just stands there.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. Wander leaves the door open, heading for the kitchen.  INT. WANDER’S KITCHEN - DEAD OF NIGHT 90. Wander makes coffee atop a fine granite counter. Ludlow s at an oak kitchen table.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: How’s that reporter of yours. (off Ludlow) Alright, how’s complaints?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (half a smile) Haven’t been there much lately.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: No, no you haven’t. (then) You can’t let it go, can you?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (whispers) These are bad guys, Terry. They’re wiping out their competition. We found a drug shack they took over in Palmdale. The previous tenants are buried in the backyard... I think I can get a face to face. Wander considers the world Ludlow has brought into his ho

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: You don’t need to whisper, Lud. (looks upstairs) Katrina’s been gone for a year.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (‘Jesus’) Okay. Am I the only one who missed that--

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: She still comes with me to certain events. There’s a political side to my job that never interested you. (then) We had a lot of late nights around this table, didn’t we? The four of us? Ludlow nods.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: I should’ve known you’d be you on this thing. Should’ve let you take the fall.  91. Ludlow wrings his face in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: I left my badge in the car when I went after Mody. I can’t hide behind it now.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: (sighs) Well I give up. You wanna lead Diskant around by the collar - teach him all your old tricks - go ahead. Go on huntin’. But whatever you two catch...don’t bring it home to the station. You do it the old way. Settle it out there. Ludlow just blinks.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: I’1l back you again. INT. CORONER’S OFFICE - DAY GOLD TEETH next to GREY ONES. Outside the cadaver’s mouth a SEEDY CORONER works with a clamp. OUTSIDE THE EXAM ROOM, Ludlow stares glassily through a window. Diskant works nearby - he’s got a TIMELINE going: the Ju Market...Fremont and Coates...Bodies in Palmdale...

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: Wait - so Mody's wife admitted Mody was dirty?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: She said if he ever was, he cleaned it up.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: You think he was working with Fremont and Coates or not? Ludlow doesn’t move.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: I’m inclined to believe...I don’t know. But everything comes down to that. Either he was, and it was a simple score being settled. (a heavy beat) Or Mody was clean, and we’re up to our necks in I-don’t-even-know-what.  92.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: (pleadingly) We found the dope in his trunk.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (scornfully) What did you find? You found an evidence tag on a torn piece of string. (then) Nobody seems to know Mody. Not Scribble, or Grill... Diskant knows where Ludlow’s heading.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: Is there any chance Mody was just wrong- place-wrong-time?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: You’re looking at Fremont and Coates’ rap sheet. You see them pulling any Mickey Mouse mini-mart holdups?

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: (sighs) They weren’t there for the register.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Okay, Junior G. So if Mody was clean, and this wasn’t a personal score being settled...

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: Somebody hired them.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (miserably) On a different score. The exhausted coroner emerges.

dialogues.speaker: CORONER
dialogues.text: LaShawn Fremont and Wade Coates.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (‘And?’) Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: CORONER
dialogues.text: Yeah, Fremont and Coates.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: What do you mean? (the exam room) In there?  93.

dialogues.speaker: CORONER
dialogues.text: On my tables.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: Fremont and Coates?

dialogues.speaker: CORONER
dialogues.text: (sarcastically) Who’s on first? Yeah, Fremont and Coates. What the hell’s wrong with you two? Diskant’s CELL PHONE rings. When he sees the number he ex reluctantly.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Dead how long?

dialogues.speaker: CORONER
dialogues.text: I’d say four to six months. Took two nines to the back of the head. No hands on either of them so I had to go dental. He hands Ludlow the bullets.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Did you say no hands?

dialogues.speaker: CORONER
dialogues.text: We’re quits now Ludlow. No more favors. The coroner retreats to his office. Ludlow just sits ther head spinning. Diskant returns, the blood drained from hi face. He holds up his cell phone--

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: It’s Scribble.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Oh yeah?

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: He’s with Fremont and Coates. Ludlow swallows. That's interesting. He motions for the p

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: I knew you were the man, Scribble. (listens) Of course we got the shit. (listens) Tonight’s real good. Where? Ludlow motions for a pen, then - deflated - waves it off.  94.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (deliberating) No, no that’s fine. You call this number with the place... And Scribble? You be there too. Ludlow hangs up. An EERIE SILENCE between the detectives.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Don’t say anything for a second. Ludlow keeps thinking... He SEES Diskant’s ready to explo

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (‘keep going gesture’) Alright, go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: (quickly) Who the fuck are we meeting tonight if Fremont and Coates are in there? And - gee, I don’t know - who killed Mody? ‘Cause I’m pretty sure these two were dead three days ago. Ludlow stares off, thinking.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: Oh man, this is fucked. I thought you knew what you were doing. (then) Okay, well somebody’s lying.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: No fucking shit Disco.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: (xe: the coroner) Maybe this old perv got it wrong.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: What, he just pulled those names out of a hat? Diskant shakes his head, finally calming.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: You saying it’s cops that made a mistake? The hair, the prints - maybe they locked in the wrong guys.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: I think we’re beyond accidents at this point, Disco.  95.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: Meaning what?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Meaning there’s a loop that you and I missed out on. I think we’re hitting on some of those big things you were promised.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: So one of ours pulled Mody’s killers off the street?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: That’s a could be.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: Okay, right now it means...the guys posing as Fremont and Coates, were posing as Fremont and Coates when they killed Mody.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: For who? For why? Diskant caves in again.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: Is there any way to find out without actually meeting them? Ludlow just smiles.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: We need more dope.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: (no big deal) We’ll sign it out.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: I hate to remind you Disco, but we’re on our own with this thing.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: So we’ll boost it. Ludlow’s head rolls back...he’s created a monster.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Your show. Diskant nods, convincing himself.  96.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: Is there time for me to roll home? Grab some of my gear?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Yeah, go kiss her goodbye. Diskant chortles. Then, somewhat dolefully--

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: Guess we should get our affairs in order. Ludlow nods; the kid’s growing on him. Ludlow’s cell phon RINGS. The display reads: ‘Megan’... He simply stares at

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ludlow stands at the door of a small home. It appears he’ been there for some time. In his hand, the VIDEOTAPE. LINDA MODY opens her front door. She contemplates Ludlow his tape, before opening the door further.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: I don’t want to intrude.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: (a hint of good nature) Well I don’t want you seen on my porch. STREET POV: from inside a parked car, we WATCH Ludlow ent the house... REVEAL Shoney and DeMille, tailing Ludlow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The floor is a surreal mix of FLOWERS and MOVING BOXES. Everything is covered in sheets - the television, furnitu except for a few standing pictures of Gilbert Mody. Ludlow still carries the videotape - his personal albatro

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Should I know what that is?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: You said you wanted to know. (searching) ---I stole it from the market that day. I was there...before he died.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Why?  97.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: I heard he was testifying...against me. I was gonna hurt him.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Did you?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: I would have... Linda’s rooted to the ground. Her stoicism breaks Ludlow

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: I thought he was trying to take what I had left. She regards the tape.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: And now I can take it. Ludlow nods, his penance complete. He starts for the door

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: I think I said something unforgivable to you. About your wife. Ludlow turns back calmly.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: You know I think I was just happy to talk about her.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: I’m sure she was lovely.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Well we weren’t that great, obviously. But I didn’t think we were that bad either. Linda looks at him, truly, for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Make room for someone else, detective. While you’re waiting for it all to make sense. (all the flowers) I’m in the club, so I can say that to you. Ludlow manages a rusty smile.  98.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: I believe you about your husband. I think he was killed for his testimony. Linda’s eyes well.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: What did he have, Mrs. Mody? Ludlow’s asking for a huge leap of faith.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: I’m not sure what I’m walking into tonight.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: (compelled) He was going to expose some sort of money skimming operation. He said it was organized like any company. Different stations coordinated... That’s all I know. Ludlow nods, his fears confirmed.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: I’1l get the rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ludlow dresses at his locker, like a Hall of Fame pitcher his last start. His routine is almost religious: a Kevlar a shoulder holster, a 9MM, ammunition, a two-inch .38 in back pocket... Diskant is the only other man in the room. He armors up quietly, appreciating the moment. Ludlow SEES Diskant holster a simple 9MM; the young cop has come a long way.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: You sure we don’t wanna roll with back- up? Couple guys...?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (wryly) Which cops did you have in mind? Diskant concedes the point.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (low; razor-sharp) Just wait ‘til you see the cash. Then we can move. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LUDLOW (cont'd) (Diskant nods) And look for the dope as soon as we get in there. If they haven’t tested it... that’s not good.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: Wait - forget the cash. We got’em on murder. Diskant hands Ludlow a BAG of DOPE.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: No, we definitely do not. Their faces were covered and somebody else... BIGGS is standing at the end of the row, his IMPOSING ASSISTANT behind him.

dialogues.speaker: BIGGS
dialogues.text: Back on the night, Tom? Weren’t grounded very long, were you? Ludlow gives Diskant a look, prompting the younger detect to excuse himself.

dialogues.speaker: BIGGS
dialogues.text: (to Diskant) Yeah, past your bed time boy.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: Fuck you. Ludlow cringes gleefully as Diskant carries on.

dialogues.speaker: BIGGS
dialogues.text: I know his name now, don’t I?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (re: Biggs’ assistant) Lose the shadow. Biggs nods the man away.

dialogues.speaker: BIGGS
dialogues.text: So you two being seen all around town.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: It’s purely social. Ludlow packs a BAG of HEROIN inside his jacket.

dialogues.speaker: BIGGS
dialogues.text: I’m surprised you’d be seen here.  100.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Well, we had to come in for some dope.

dialogues.speaker: BIGGS
dialogues.text: (re: the bags) That it?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: No, this I stole from a dealer I know. Ludlow closes his locker, locked and loaded.

dialogues.speaker: BIGGS
dialogues.text: You really think I’m gonna do nothing about you?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Here’s what I really think Terrell. I think for all your huffing and puffing, you’re not quite ready to do my job. You’re too good to go into your own alleys...clean up the needles and baby parts. You need me for all that. And more importantly-- (face to face as he passes) --you need me to blame.

dialogues.speaker: BIGGS
dialogues.text: Is this you working against them?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: I keep telling you Terrell. I don’t know who they are. Biggs gauges Ludlow’s sincerity.

dialogues.speaker: BIGGS
dialogues.text: But you’re waking up, son. (calling after) You keep my number Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A 16 year-old RUNNER carries a test bag away from Ludlow’ Camaro. Scribble waits outside the car - Lud and Disco in

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (breaking the tension) Y’alright teddy bear?  101.

dialogues.speaker: SCRIBBLE
dialogues.text: These is bad dudes, White. If they can’t fuck it, rob it or kill it, they don’t want it. Cats like that don’t like getting ganked - ‘specially by someone like me.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Nobody’s getting ‘ganked’ Scribble. This is a business deal. Ludlow rolls the window up, turning subtly to Diskant.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Jesus. But Diskant is just as spooked as Scribble.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Listen, Disco. I trust you to back me up. Maybe you should do it from outside. I’m not used to working with someone anyway. Diskant turns curiously to Ludlow.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: This is all on their terms right now... You don’t have to know the way I do.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: (swallows) No, this is my show. I’m including myself. God knows I’m not gonna be part of much else after this. Ludlow half-smiles as Scribble KNOCKS on the window.

dialogues.speaker: SCRIBBLE
dialogues.text: Looks like your shit passed. A LIGHT FLASHES out a fifth-story window.

dialogues.speaker: SCRIBBLE
dialogues.text: You gonna kill’em right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scribble exhales, KNOCKS LOUDLY over music inside. Ludlow waits behind him. His focus is in stark contrast to the Ludlow we first met. Diskant stares back, down a shadowy hall, as the DOOR OPE Ludlow eases Scribble forward, almost like a shield.  102.

Last in, Diskant looks around the opened door for the OTH KILLER when he feels the muzzle of a .38 against his temp [The gunman calls himself FREMONT, his partner COATES, so will too. ]

dialogues.text: Move to the fucking wall.

dialogues.speaker: SCRIBBLE
dialogues.text: Nah, they cool man--

dialogues.speaker: COATES
dialogues.text: Shut the fuck up, Scribble! Diskant doesn’t budge, but he’s about to lose his cool.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Nobody’s unpacking anything. We’re here to do business and we don’t do it blind. (to Fremont) You wanna feel my partner down, go ahead. But he’s not taking it out for you. A tense beat. Suddenly Coates breaks out laughing.

dialogues.speaker: COATES
dialogues.text: Oh shit! You wanna touch his junk LaShawn? (a grin with Ludlow) Nigga take a seat at my table. You pass that test. Chill the fuck out LaShawn, Scribble say they cool. Ludlow sits across from Coates, Diskant staying by the do

dialogues.speaker: COATES
dialogues.text: Ain’t that right, Scribble?

dialogues.speaker: SCRIBBLE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: COATES
dialogues.text: (mockingly) Yeah. Make us some drinks teddy bear. Teddy Bear. Ludlow’s nickname for Scribble. Ludlow peeks Diskant, but the younger detective is fixed on the TEST B it lies UNOPENED on a side table.  103.

dialogues.speaker: COATES
dialogues.text: Shoot, we got the po-po in da’ house. Ain’t that some shit? Yo, there any straight cops left? Ludlow places the second BAG of HEROIN on the table.

dialogues.speaker: COATES
dialogues.text: S’up Po-po? Talking to you.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Yeah, we’re the po-po.

dialogues.speaker: COATES
dialogues.text: You got a badge? Ludlow tosses it to him. Coates flashes it at Fremont--

dialogues.speaker: COATES
dialogues.text: Yo nigga! You under arrest!

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Like I told Scribble, we’re not in this for a quick score. We just wanted to show you a few inefficiencies in your system. It’s vulnerable, obviously. We can protect you--

dialogues.speaker: COATES
dialogues.text: Shit, you cops is like weeds, you know that? You pull one out, two more grow in.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (carefully now) Well, Mody probably got greedy. Ludlow waits... no reaction from Coates.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: We’re not trying to get rich here. We just wanna put away a little on the side for our families...

dialogues.speaker: COATES
dialogues.text: Yeah, you thinking Bahamas someday? ‘Bahamas’... The Mody's plans... Ludlow is thrown.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: What’s that now?  104.

dialogues.speaker: COATES
dialogues.text: You know: better cars, better trips-- (at Diskant) --better honeymoons. Diskant - engagement ring on his finger - want out of thi room. Ludlow, on the other hand, is suddenly distracted b THE 50 cal. MACHINE GUN (from our opening), sitting in a corner. It’s a kind of altar, wrapped in small white ligh However it got here, it mesmerizes Ludlow.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: Ludlow...

dialogues.speaker: FREMONT
dialogues.text: Yo, check this Wade. (Ludlow’s badge) Ain’t this the nigga from the market that day?

dialogues.speaker: COATES
dialogues.text: (a slow burn) Goddamn. That was you wasn’t it? Ludlow. That why you here? You want some revenge for that nigga?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: You did me a fucking favor that day. I just want to know who else I should thank. Scribble sweats in a corner of the room.

dialogues.speaker: COATES
dialogues.text: (dead serious) You that good, po-po? You know there was someone else?

dialogues.speaker: SCRIBBLE
dialogues.text: c’mon fellas, let’s sample their shit.

dialogues.speaker: COATES
dialogues.text: Shut the fuck up Scribble.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: (overlapping) Ludlow... Ludlow finally turns to Diskant.

dialogues.speaker: DISKANT
dialogues.text: There’s no cash coming out--  105. BLAM! Coates has shot Diskant in the head... The young detective is DEAD BEFORE HE HITS THE GROUND. Ludlow dives behind the couch. Stuffing punches out all around him. He FIRES wildly back, the dealers retreating. FREMONT ducks into a BATHROOM off to one side, COATES int KITCHEN off to the other. The sounds of Hispanic women SCREAMING through the walls. Ludlow’s hands shake as he reloads. Near to him, Diskant’ lifeless eyes cast into the dirty carpet.

dialogues.speaker: FREMONT
dialogues.text: You under arrest po-po! Ludlow EMPTIES a CLIP, diving to a nearby closet. Crumpled on the floor, Scribble clutches his bleeding abd Ludlow, Fremont and Coates can’t see each other, but they all see Scribble.

dialogues.speaker: COATES
dialogues.text: Scribble, pick that gun the fuck up and shoot that mothafucka! Scribble sees Diskant’s gun lying on the floor. He ignore it when... BLAM! A shot from the kitchen tears into his c

dialogues.speaker: COATES
dialogues.text: Next one peels your cap nigga! Scribble fumbles the gun into his shaking hand.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Cedric, don’t fucking do it!

dialogues.speaker: COATES
dialogues.text: ‘Cedric’? What that? Your slave name? You best fuckin’ do it! Aimed at Ludlow, Scribble slowly lowers the gun. He can’t it. He’s instantly RIDDLED WITH BULLETS from the kitchen. Peeking around the corner, Ludlow sees Fremont advance to couch. Fremont FIRES, covering Coates as he crosses to th bathroom. They’re like a trained combat unit, positioning the kill. Running out of options, Ludlow keys on the BAGS of HEROIN takes careful aim, POPPING BOTH BAGS and filling the air CHINA WHITE.  106. With a deep breath, Ludlow wades into the CLOUDY ROOM. He WINGED by a shot, but keeps moving forward... FREMONT’S POV: he’s unable to see two feet in front of hi until... LUDLOW’S RIGHT THERE. BLAM! Fremont’s gone. Coates is caught reloading in the narrow kitchen when Lud aims and FIRES... CLUNK. His 9MM jams. Coates is ready. He FIRES as LUDLOW ducks behind the fridge. As Ludlow withstands the shots - FRIDGE denting - he eyes Diskant on the ground. Dead and

dialogues.speaker: COATES
dialogues.text: You done Ludlow! I do you like I did him! Ludlow’s temper seems to boil - he’s had enough of this - he PUSHES THE FRIDGE like a linebacker in a football dril He drives it right into Coates, pinning him against the w In a heartbeat, Ludlow pulls the snub-nose from his back scales the fridge - and FIRES DOWN through Coates’ skull. Ludlow slides down off the fridge, totally spent. He goes Coates, checking his pockets, desperate for any clue...

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Who? ..-But there’s nothing. Nothing to go on. He has failed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ludlow drags Diskant out, propping him gently against the wall. He sits beside him... unable to look at his friend. SIRENS in the distance. Ludlow takes a deep breath - rise and walks away... EXT. MEGAN’S HOME - NIGHT Ludlow limps up steps, bleeding from his shoulder down hi sleeve. Megan opens the door before he knocks, her face covered in tears.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Why are you crying? She almost smiles, helping him inside.  107. INT. MEGAN’S HOME - MOMENTS LATER Ludlow sits on the floor, back against her couch. Megan rushes out of the bathroom, tape and gauze in her hands.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: .»-jJust wanted a name. We couldn’t get it. He pulls his arm away from her.

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: Just let me do this. Megan tries to compose herself as she wraps the bandage.

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: (trying to convince herself) It’s gonna be okay. It’s gonna be okay.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: She’1ll get nothing.

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: She doesn’t get a pension ‘cause they didn’t do it yet. She’s probably still sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: Lud, just take it easy. What are you saying?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: I walked him in there. (turns to her) It went bad Megan. Megan’s still crying her own tears.

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (recurring to him) Wait, why were you crying? Megan looks back at her TV, on in the background.  108.

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: They called me to cover it. I didn’t go because it was you. Ludlow drags himself to the TV: helicopter images of the IMPERIAL COURTS BUILDINGS. Then a graphic appears: LUDLOW’ S ACADEMY PHOTOGRAPH. He looks young in his blues his eyes clear and hopeful. A REPORTER and ANALYST go back and forth over the images- ANALYST’S VOICE (ON TV) ...the loss of his wife last year. He’s had a history of violence and complaints against him that have made him a well- known figure in this community. But this - you don’t see something like this coming. REPORTER’S VOICE (ON TV) Again, the details just coming in... Detective Tom Ludlow, a twenty-year man on the force...wanted for the slaying of two undercover officers in the early hours this morning. Two more Academy photographs replace Ludlow’s: TWO YOUNG, CLEAN-CUT BLACK OFFICERS... the men representi themselves as dealers Fremont and Coates. REPORTER’S VOICE (ON TV) Ludlow and Detective Paul Diskant were attempting to sell a large quantity of narcotics to the undercover officers when the shooting occurred. Ludlow is simply...destroyed. A ticker runs along the bot of the screen: COP WANTED IN SLAYING OF THREE FELLOW OFFICERS. REPORTER’S VOICE (ON TV) Detective Ludlow is at large and also wanted for questioning in the murder of Officer Gilbert Mody, killed last week in a Korea Town grocery...

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: Lud? Lud? Megan watches Ludlow disintegrate.  109.

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: We won’t let them, Lud. You can fight this. Please don’t give in like this. (crying) Please, you’re scaring me...

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: You don’t understand...

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: I should’ve known they were cops; I couldn’t see it... I couldn’t think it. (then) All I saw were two...

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: No, I know it’s not true. People will listen, Lud. What are you gonna do--

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (resignedly) No. There’s only ‘how it looks’. Now, finally, Megan quiets. She looks about...lost. Then- KNOCK ON THE DOOR. Ludlow suddenly panics.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (the bandages) Get these off me.

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: What? MAN’S VOICE (0.S.) Police!

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: You don’t want me here. You didn’t open the door! He tears off his bandages, handing them to her.

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: No, I don’t want to do this--

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (for all to hear) Open the fucking door! (to her) You gotta scream Megan. Do it or they’1l kill you.  110.

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: What? He SLAPS HER hard. She cries as he SHOVES HER into her be

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Do it!

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: Tell me you’1l meet me at the station.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (shaking her) Scream!

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: No! Tell me... It’s an isolated, peaceful millisecond between them.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Alright... Now fucking scream.

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: (blood-curdling) Help!! She slams the door between them, just as - BOOM! - the FR DOOR is kicked in. SHONEY and DEMILLE advance, guns on Ludlow.

dialogues.speaker: BOTH MEN
dialogues.text: Down! On the fucking floor Ludlow! Ludlow drops to his knees, hands on his head.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: You fucking bitch!

dialogues.speaker: DEMILLE
dialogues.text: Shut up! Shoney throws Ludlow down, taking his piece and cuffing h DeMille KICKS IN Megan’s door, finding her crying on the cell phone to her ear... A trickle of blood on her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: Oh, thank God. DeMille stares a calculating beat... Then lowers his gun.

dialogues.speaker: DEMILLE
dialogues.text: It’s alright honey. You’re alright now.  111.

dialogues.speaker: SHONEY
dialogues.text: Let’s go. DeMille reluctantly peels his eyes off Megan.

dialogues.speaker: DEMILLE
dialogues.text: Alright. Get him up and out. Megan watches tearfully as Ludlow’s led roughly off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DeMille’s sedan cruises along an open freeway, away from city lights. INT. DEMILLE’S CAR - CONTINUOUS Ludlow rides in the backseat, his head resting against th window. He’s resigned now... No fight left. He takes in the passing terrain...sand and brush in the moonlight. His eyes catch DeMille’s in the rearview mirro

dialogues.speaker: DEMILLE
dialogues.text: (to Shoney; re: Megan) Not the most loyal girl, was she? Gimme some tips Ludlow. How do I console that hot reporter ass after you’re gone? (then) c’mon. I know you whisper all sorts of sweet things to Mody's widow. Shoney turns around to Ludlow.

dialogues.speaker: SHONEY
dialogues.text: You fuck’em both, right? Which one you like better?

dialogues.speaker: DEMILLE
dialogues.text: (no more jokes) Shouldn’t have given her that tape Lud.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: The fuck are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: SHONEY
dialogues.text: (to DeMille) Take it easy--

dialogues.speaker: DEMILLE
dialogues.text: No, I want him to know before we do it. Smug fuckin’ prick. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DEMILLE (cont'd) You figure it out yet? How Fremont and Coates made it to the market that day? Very slowly, Ludlow slides his handcuffs from behind his to under his thighs...

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: You killed them instead of arrest them.

dialogues.speaker: DEMILLE
dialogues.text: They hadn’t made it a mile out of the station before we picked’em back up and peeled their fucking caps.

dialogues.speaker: SHONEY
dialogues.text: No papers, no friends, no relatives. (turns to Ludlow) It was my idea.

dialogues.speaker: DEMILLE
dialogues.text: Anyway, a little hair, a little blood. It’s the ultimate get-outta-jail card. (xvhetorically) Gotta get rid of a rat piece of shit like Mody? ‘Fremont and Coates did it.’

dialogues.speaker: SHONEY
dialogues.text: You ruined a very good thing for us boy. Very subtly, Ludlow lifts his knees, trying to get his ha in front of himself.

dialogues.speaker: DEMILLE
dialogues.text: We gave you a lot of rope on this one Ludlow. We even let Mody's widow live this long with what she knows... And she fucking knows with that pussy-boy husband of hers. But you’ve fucked that up for both of you now.

dialogues.speaker: SHONEY
dialogues.text: Guess whose hair and blood’s gonna be all over her place? (to DeMille) Shit, maybe we should have him rape her too.

dialogues.speaker: DEMILLE
dialogues.text: (howling) Ho, I’1l let you handle that! In one motion, Ludlow clears the handcuffs under his feet THROWS THEM AROUND DeMILLE’S NECK. He hangs on - like an animal that won’t release it’s hold - as Shoney bashes hi skull.  113. DeMille swerves on the freeway as Shoney HAMMERS the butt of his 9MM into Ludlow’s head - again and again - until finally, as the LAST BLOW impacts, we-- cuT TO BLACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ludlow’s eyes open slowly... his blood congeals on dusty concrete. He’s lying on his cheek. OLEANDER BRUSH waves i the BRIGHT MOONLIGHT. DeMille’s suddenly in his face, swabbing blood from his s into a VIAL. He speaks softly, triumphantly, in Ludlow’s

dialogues.speaker: DEMILLE
dialogues.text: Aw, poor Tommy. I know what you’re really wondering. How could they leave me out? Ludlow coughs, choking on his own blood.

dialogues.speaker: DEMILLE
dialogues.text: You were almost approached, you know. If you can believe that. But you were just too selfish to be trusted. Just a low- class drunken loud mouth out for himself. (then; rising) You should’ve kept more friends, Ludlow. DeMille leaves Ludlow on the ground, taking the vial insi Ludlow’s eyes dart about - looking for a play - but his b is unresponsive. He wilts without moving... It’s all over Then, a WIND picks up, ruffling the OLEANDER BRUSH before him. Still handcuffed, Ludlow’s breathing rises...his fac flushes...he’s not ready to quit just yet. He begins crawling, still handcuffed, towards the brush.

dialogues.speaker: DEMILLE
dialogues.text: (kidding around) Hey, Shones!! Get out here! He’s making a run for it! The FIRST SHOT explodes in the sand by Ludlow’s ear. The brush is still fifteen feet away...

dialogues.speaker: SHONEY
dialogues.text: Where you going Lud?!  114. BLAM! Another shot near Ludlow’s hip. They FIRE over and over, toying with Ludlow. A BULLET rips into his calf. CLOSE on LUDLOW. Not done yet. FIVE FEET to the brush.

dialogues.speaker: DEMILLE
dialogues.text: He’s gonna bury himself! MORE SHOTS in the sand all around him... TWO FEET... Then drawing from way down, he finds the strength to scurry in the thick brush. DeMille looks partly flustered, mainly annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: SHONEY
dialogues.text: Let’s just do him and get going.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE BRUSH,
dialogues.text: Ludlow crawls through SWARMING RED ANTS... he’s going tow the BURIAL HOLE... And, just beyond it... DISKANT’S SHOVE

dialogues.speaker: DEMILLE
dialogues.text: This is it Lud. I’m not gonna say I haven’t enjoyed this, but I’1l make it quick for you. He finds Ludlow on his back, exhausted, hands over his he DeMille gets right on top of him... He raises his gun... When Ludlow’s hands extend from the brush, bringing the S to DeMille’s forehead. Shoney charges into the brush, FIRING at Ludlow as he dra DeMille backwards, the two of them folding INTO THE GRAVE Shoney gets overtop of the grave, FIRING down... From ben the cover of DeMille, Ludlow SHOOTS STRAIGHT UP, killing Shoney instantly... .--Using his feet, Ludlow pushes DeMille out of the grave Then, summoning all his strength, he LIFTS HIMSELF OUT... He coughs up dirt and blood...back from the dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linda walks through her living room - still littered with boxes and flowers - to answer her front door. She opens i Finding Clady on her doorstep. He smiles over the chain l  115. INT. LIVING ROOM, WANDER’S HOME - NIGHT Wander sits in his robe - middle of the night - glued to television. It’s as if Ludlow’s story, still breaking new has sucked the life out of him. We stay on him, over-- ANCHOR’S VOICE (ON TV) As far as we know Officer Ludlow is still at large. Again, a police spokesperson saying Ludlow is to be considered armed and dangerous. CO-ANCHOR’S VOICE (ON TV) Strange to hear the police use that kind of terminology on one of their own. ANCHOR’S VOICE (ON TV) Absolutely...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CABINET smashes as Clady chases Linda through her home. pins her in a corner, her nose already dripping with bloo

dialogues.speaker: CLADY
dialogues.text: This place is a fucking mess, you know that? Where is it? Huh? Where’s the fucking tape? (slaps her viciously) Look at you - getting your nigger blood all over me. Linda turns her head away, trying to imagine herself somewhere else. Clady glimpses a VCR atop of a moving box

dialogues.speaker: CLADY
dialogues.text: Is that a VCR? Released for a moment, Linda slides down the wall, into a heap. As Clady checks the VCR - smashing it when he finds empty - Linda glimpses LUDLOW looking in a window. Linda’s head falls forward - a kind of exhausted, euphori release. She knows her trial is over. None the wiser, Clady returns to her - angrier than ever. picks her up, momentarily bemused as she smiles through t

dialogues.speaker: CLADY
dialogues.text: You’re a tough a little cunt, aren’t you? Tougher than that husband of yours. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLADY (cont'd) (then) What’s so funny? Huh?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Bye bye now. One second Clady is there, the next - as if hit by a bus he’s gone. Ludlow tackles him to the floor, wrenching the air from his lungs and BREAKING HIS ARM as he cuffs him. Linda turns away as Clady howls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ludlow drags an unconscious Clady to his ‘requisitioned’ vehicle (Shoney and DeMille’s unmarked car). He stuffs th Sergeant into the trunk as Linda watches from her doorste

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: You gotta go now Linda. Wherever it is, you have to go.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: (wryly) I’m already packed. Ludlow takes the cue, slowing for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: I found them. The men who killed--

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: I know who you mean.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Well, I wanted to arrest them, but...it didn’t work out that way. Linda recovers from the news, still in tatters.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Take care of yourself Officer. Ludlow nods, bittersweetly. Nothing left to say.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Goodnight. A cell phone is RINGING... from inside the trunk. Ludlow opens it, grabbing CLADY’S PHONE...

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: Yeah.  117. MAN’S VOICE (FROM PHONE) Jesus, nobody’s answering - what’s going on out there? Is it over or not? Ludlow goes pale.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: Terry?

dialogues.speaker: WITH
dialogues.text: INT. KITCHEN, WANDER’S HOME - CONTINUOUS Phone to his ear, Wander stands over his sink, staring in his backyard. He’s just as speechless.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: Lud? Wander sets down a coffee mug.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: Where’s Clady?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: Trunk.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: Shoney and DeMille?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: Palmdale. Ludlow takes a breath, begins to process. He smiles bitte

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: I guess you all had me right... I never could see a move ahead.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: Now listen. Before you do anything else... We should talk. You owe me that much.... Lud? EXT. WANDER’S HOME - EARLY DAWN Ludlow drives over the curb, onto the grass. He’s brought Wander’s whole scheme back to him, and parked it on his f lawn. Ludlow pulls his 9MM, retrieved from Shoney’s dead body, sliding his hand along the rack. He clears the chamber, t  118. DROPS OUT the clip... Contemplates the bullets. INT. WANDER’S HOME - MOMENTS LATER Ludlow enters cautiously, weapon drawn.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hell of a parking job. Ludlow follows the voice, limping to the--

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Wander sits passively, TWO COFFEES on the kitchen table.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Put your hands on the table. Wander obliges, nothing - apparently - up his sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: Sit down, you can still point that at me. Ludlow’s head swivels, watching his own back.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: It’s just you and me. And so...Ludlow joins him at the table.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: You wearing a wire?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Just you and me.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: -..It started with a hundred dollars. We were tangling with thugs that had better armor than us. I stole a hundred dollars to get a better vest. Ludlow’s listening...but he’s also digging in his jacket. He places SHONEY’S BADGE on the table.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: The lawsuits started about the same time in this state. (bitterly) Sue anybody for anything. Especially cops. (then) They went after Silky personally. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WANDER (cont'd) Took his home from him... The rest of us started pooling together. Ludlow places DeMILLE’S BADGE on the table.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: The suits got bigger so we started skimming more. Even if we weren’t in trouble we’d just keep pooling together, just to be ready for the next one. CLADY’S BADGE on the table.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: Got to be that, when we were in the black, we’d pay out here and there. Nobody’s buying yachts or summer homes. Just a natural correction in a flawed system. Christ, Lud, if teachers could do it they would too.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: That help you sleep at night?

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: Fuck you. (the badges) What are those? Scalps? For old time’s sake, Ludlow makes his ‘keep going’ gestur

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Keep going. I want to hear you get to the part where we murder, and deal, and kill other cops.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: (mock innocence) I don’t know what you mean.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Mody.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: Not a cop.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Fuck you - be a man. You put them on me.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: I held them off you - long as I could. I had to put you down, Lud. You don’t listen. I’ve given you so much rope... (darkly) You don’t know what you are, do you?  120.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: I know my part in this.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: Do you Lud? C’mon...those kids in Little Saigon? You could’ve waited for backup; they weren’t going anywhere. But you didn’t like’em. So you killed’em. And the world’s a better place for it. (then) You decided what justice was, and I backed you. Because I trust you know right from wrong. That’s how it works... Or you’re a killer. Ludlow teases the trigger on his 9MM.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Forget it. Forget the drugs and the money. (astounded; offended) You got cops killing cops. You got me killing cops. And then you come after me? (quiet, blistering rage) After everything. The four of us around this table, huh? When did this start making sense to you?

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: You wanna make this personal. I understand that. But you were just in the way.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Of what? Your corporation.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: of a system that was working Tom. Everybody happy. We did the job on the street and took care of our own. You and Mody fucked that up.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: All for a little green?

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: I’m the father of a very large family. And we’ve gotta survive Tom. Welcome to the big picture.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: No. No more big picture. No more ‘changing with the times’. We’re not going with your version this time.  121.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: Our version. Ludlow nods, conceding his part in their play.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: I allow you to exist Lud. You tear me down you make us both extinct. Ten years - we’ll all be like firemen. Just sitting around waiting for phone calls because it’s too risky - too expensive to go out and stop something. Ludlow smiles sadly. Wander takes it for defeat.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: You’re not gonna ruin us both.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: I’m saved Terry... Even if I’m as fucked as you are. Ludlow pulls a LAST BADGE out of his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: This one’s Diskant’s. Ludlow just holds it there, letting it burn into Wander. From total surrender, Wander moves slowly to rage...

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: I’m not going through this. The media, the bullshit system, like some Joe Public schmuck. You want to end me, then you do it. You owe me that! Ludlow smiles as he rises; he’s not going to shoot Wander Wander sprays his coffee over Ludlow, TOSSING THE TABLE.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: Fuck you! This is what you want, then you be a man and do it! Ludlow stands his ground, dripping. He stares into his ol friend’s eyes, and places his 9MM on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: I’m done killing cops. And you don’t know better than those schmucks, you arrogant prick. Wander sobs as Ludlow turns away. Then... Ludlow HEARS a ‘CLICK’. He turns to find Wander pointing his 9MM at him.  122.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: All you do is make heroes Lud. First Mody... Those nigger cops you killed tonight... And now me. For stopping you.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: You’re gonna do it yourself now?

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: Self-defense Lud. You’re a crazed killer. Ludlow’s rage builds as Wander tightens on the trigger...

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: It was me by the way. I took her to the hospital that night. Should’ve been you. (then; finally) I was fucking your wife Tom. Ludlow absorbs what he’s always wondered...and always kno

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: I know. Still aimed at Ludlow, Wander PULLS THE TRIGGER... CLICK. Nothing. CLICK. CLICK. The magazine is empty.

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: You gotta be kidding... Ludlow begins rolling up his sleeves.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: That felt personal. Wander drops the gun, rolling up his own sleeves. Both me wait until the other is ready. And then, with a shared no BOOM! They collide like two rams, locking and grappling. SOUND DROPS OUT, except for their BREATHING. They snort a gasp as each lands CRUSHING BLOWS... There’s absolutely nothing sexy about it. This is what it takes to be Ludlow; what nobody out there wants to know a He lands ONE MORE BLOW than his old friend, overpowering He turns Wander over, cuffing him--

dialogues.speaker: WANDER
dialogues.text: No! No! Wo! Ludlow slumps against the wall. Out of breath, bleeding everywhere. He slowly, painfully pulls out his phone.  123.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: This is 41 Adam. Officer down. 408 Oak street... Send rescue. EXT. WANDER’S HOME - MOMENTS LATER Biggs waits patiently, leaning on the hood of DeMille’s sedan. He watches Ludlow hobble out of Wander’s house...

dialogues.speaker: BIGGS
dialogues.text: Rough night?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: First on scene?

dialogues.speaker: BIGGS
dialogues.text: Came as soon as you called. I was hoping it’d be you that walked out.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Just sit back and let us all kill each other. That the idea?

dialogues.speaker: BIGGS
dialogues.text: You’re not all the same to me Ludlow. (sincerely) You’re not them. Ludlow’s too tired to react. SIRENS near.

dialogues.speaker: BIGGS
dialogues.text: Self-defense? It’s all ‘how it sounds’, you know?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Whatever you say boss.

dialogues.speaker: BIGGS
dialogues.text: You got keys to this thing? There’s somebody in the trunk I wouldn’t mind speaking with. Ludlow tosses him the keys, hobbling off on his way.

dialogues.speaker: BIGGS
dialogues.text: Where you walking son? As TWO BLACK AND WHITE’S pull up, Biggs holds up his badg shielding Ludlow.  124.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The busy station comes to a grinding halt...as LUDLOW WAL He limps down the long hallway - no one making a sound. He stares up at a DESK SERGEANT, who knowingly points him down the hall, deeper into the lion’s den. At the end, he finds MEGAN standing plaintively at a high She turns from the clerk ignoring her... FINDING LUDLOW.. Megan gathers her purse, composes herself, and walks to h side. They don’t touch or speak - but she sees that he’s still there... still in one piece.
